title: How to find my passion - Quora

response.answer_text: Ever say to yourself, "If I could just figure out what I'm really passionate about, everything else will take off"? If so, you're not alone. One of the most common stumbling blocks to launching a passion-based life is figuring out what you're passionate about in the first place. Sadly, many of us go about finding our passion in the wrong way. How? By thinking about it. We're habituated to use our minds to analyze, rationalize and figure things out. It's natural yet oooooh so torturesome. Common techniques to find passion include: Taking expensive psychological testsRecalling childhood interestsSitting at Starbucks watching your friend's eyes glaze over after asking questions like "I don't know...what do you think I should do?"Here's the problem: Passion can't be found in your head because it lives in your heart. And the flames of passion are fanned by engagement, not thought. Juicy, right? Here's what I mean: No matter how hard you try, you cannot figure out your passion by thinking about it. You need to take action and feel your way to your truth, from the inside out. For example, for years, before I stepped foot in a dance studio, I often wondered about dancing hip-hop. But most of my thoughts sounded like this: "Wow...dancing professionally would be awesome, but you're too old to get started. Most pros start training when they're 5. You've had zero professional training, and you're already in your 20s. Get real." Or, "It sounds exciting, but dance as a career is crazy and irresponsible. There's no money in that. You studied business finance, so you should do something more stable and related to what you know." The endless and debilitating chatter in our minds often tries to talk us out of what our hearts are yearning to explore. The first time I took a class in a professional dance setting, I started to cry (happy tears, of course) because actually doing it felt right. No matter how much I wondered about it before, it wasn't until I physically took action that my real passion (and gift) for dance fully emerged. And from taking action rather than staying in my head, I was able to carve out a little niche for myself in the hybrid world of dance and fitness. Rather than following traditional hip-hop dancer goals (like going on tour with major recording artists or auditioning for music videos), I was asked to become one of the world's first Nike Elite Dance Athletes—a category Nike created after I got started. Not to get too woo-woo on you, but magic really does start to happen when you follow your heart. Embrace this key idea and it will change your life: Clarity comes from engagement, not thought. But taking action on something you suspect to be your passion is just part of the story. There's another important (and rarely discussed) piece to the passion puzzle. And this, my friend, is the fastest, most powerful way to turn what you love into a business or career that can sustain you. Ready? Proactively bring passion to everything you touch, to everything you do. No matter what task is in front of you, bring as much enthusiasm and energy to it as you possibly can. Bring your full attention, your full presence, the Godlike quality that each of us has within, to every task in your day. Whether you're brushing your teeth, making love or cleaning the kitty litter—do it like you want to do it. When you make this shift, you'll ignite business ideas and creative insights far beyond what your thinking mind alone is capable of. And let's face it. Passion is contagious. When you're fully present and passionately engaged with your life, people around you take notice and want in on whatever you're doing. Want more? Another side benefit to proactive passion is kicking life-sucking habits like procrastination, resistance and complaining straight to the curb. Now that you're armed with an understanding of passion, do the following four steps to unleash yours. 4 Steps to Find Your Passion 1. Love everything you do. From this moment forward, if you don't like something, you've got two choices: stop doing it (quit, delegate it, hire it out) OR love it with all your heart. Anything else is madness. When you commit to love everything you do, you strengthen your "passion muscles" from the inside out and open up a divine channel so that what you're meant to do can be revealed. Remember, we human beings are creatures of habit. You can't be whiny, complainy and miserable for 80 percent of your day and expect to be enthusiastic and passionate in the last 20 percent. And if you're feeling really stuck on this whole "finding your passion" thing, this is the fastest way to get your motor running. Know this: Truly successful people are never the victim of their circumstances. They realize they have ultimate power in any situation and take responsibility for their experience. Don't forget: In any given moment, if you can't change what you're doing, you can always change how you're doing it. 2. Look at your book collection, magazines, DVDs, CDs and credit card statements. Notice any themes? What subjects are you constantly gravitating toward? What are you already spending your time, money and energy on? What thread(s) have been recurring in your life again and again? As best as you can, check in with your heart and physical body, not your head. Anything "light you up" so to speak? Do you feel a sense of expansion in your body? Do you feel excitement (or perhaps even a little fear) when you imagine a certain topic or possibility? Those are all good signs. Remember, our passions are often irrational and war with logic and reason. That's why it's important to shift your attention into your heart and your physical body when exploring these questions. Your heart and physical body contain wisdom far beyond the capacity of your mind. 3. What do you love to talk about, learn about and/or teach others about? This is a really useful question. Don't edit yourself here. With nearly 7 billion people on the planet, chances are that there's a market out there hungry for information, products or resources on your topic. Or there's a company looking for someone with your unique set of gifts and interests to join their team. If you're having trouble coming up with ideas, ask close friends and family (the honest ones) what you never seem to shut up about. Also, don't underestimate the power of incorporating your passion into your already existing career or business. You may not need a total overhaul in what you're doing. Maybe you simply need to inject more of what you LOVE into your life right now. For example, Nathalie, a raw-food expert, recently rediscovered her passion for growing trees. Now she's giving a portion of her revenue to not-for-profit tree organizations and is building this component into her existing brand. With that tiny tweak, she just gave herself a competitive advantage over other raw-food experts who aren't passionate about any cause (or brave enough to share it), and she is way more motivated to market and sell her products and services because they're tied to making a bigger difference in the world. 4. Quit talking and start doing. Now that you've gotten this far, the next step is to begin taking consistent passion-based action each day. That could mean writing, making videos, recording audios, taking a class or somehow engaging in an activity you love. And here's the best part. Taking action on your passion often requires little to no cash outlay. Articles, videos and writing take no money. Only time, effort and focus. And beginner classes can often be inexpensive or, sometimes, even free. Building your life around what you love is something you'll never regret. It's your passion for what you do that will give you the drive, commitment and energy necessary to create any amount of success and fulfillment you desire, and you'll have an extraordinary time while you do it. That’s everything you need to know about finding your passion and probably a little more because I just can’t help myself, I’m passionate about sharing this work with you. Now go ahead and get started and don’t forget to let me know how it goes! Good luck :)

You actually don’t find a passion for your life, as much as you discover what your passions are. When you know your passions, as well as knowing who you are, you create a life filled with passion. You allow your truth to guide you in the decisions you make, and ultimately, the life you create for yourself. Many people have the feeling that life drags them around or determines their happiness, or even their life circumstances. What they don’t realize, is that you have the power to create your own life and therefore, you level of happiness or joy. It sound simplistic, and in actuality it is. But there’s definitely effort, as well as courage involved. The easy thing is to just follow the status quo - to do what everyone else says you should do, or what everyone else is doing. That leads to a life-humbling experience, and in many cases even depression because when you do that, you’re so far out of alignment with what makes you feel alive, that it creates an inner turmoil. So how do you go about doing this? Start by looking at what you either like, or love. If you can’t get to the place just yet or what really excites you, or what you love, then go with what interests you or what you like. This is just a directional indication. When you give yourself permission to explore what you like (or love), you find yourself led in new directions - trying new things. You start to open up to possibilities - exposing yourself to new experiences, people, or opportunities. One of the best things you can do is to learn to tune into your inner wisdom. Your gut instinct. What “feels” right? What feels “off”? When you being to get a feel for that, your decisions become more authentic for what’s right for you. This is the important part - what’s right for you! Not for me, not for your neighbored, best friend, or colleague. Because what’s right for you is exactly what will lead you to be a better person, expand your horizon, and even make a much bigger difference in the world. The process of discovering your passion and then allowing yourself to do it is a multi-layered process. The more you work on it, the better for you - the better results you’ll find you have. There are several steps, but mostly they’re: Give yourself permission to dream, to imagine and to look at what pulls you - what excites you and gets your heart beating faster? This isn’t a small step for most people. You have to be willing to examine all of the messages or examples other people gave you that told you to “Play it safe”, “fit in”, or “Don’t stand out”. You have to go against what you’ve learned - which is to be careful and ignore what you’re passionate about, if it goes against the norm.Once you discover what it is that creates life and excitement within you, or what just feels right on, then you need the courage to do something about it. This is the next step. This means you have to possibly dismantle old beliefs or even old patterns of doing.Then take action steps to put it in place.And then refine all of this. Pursue your passion. Find a way to fit it into your life. And live it courageously, with no apologies to anyone.I’ve written several articles on passion, doing what you love, and removing blocks to passion. Below are some links if you’d want to read further on how to discover and implement your passions. What Makes You Come Alive? Find It and Live It. Removing the Blocks to Passion and Purpose How can I find my passion? Pursuing What You Love to Find Real Happiness In terms of implementing the steps, this is a great book on taking small, manageable steps to accomplish your goals. In this case, creating your life filled with passion and purpose. The Slight Edge: Turning Simple Disciplines into Massive Success And Happiness, by Jeff Olson. It’s a very simple read on how to start making changes now. I hope you do pursue what drives you and what you’re passionate about. It’s the absolute best thing you can do in life - for yourself, as well as the people around you. All the best, -Sumi Connecting individuals to passion & purpose

I found my passion the moment I had a bottle full of pills in my mouth and I had the choice whether to swallow them or not.  I had carefully researched what would do the trick. But I was worried if I swallowed the pills then the insurance companies wouldn't pay my kids $4 million in life insurance.  They have a funny thing about being judgmental on suicide. Suicide is a horrible thing for kids.  I know this because my wife's mother killed herself. Sometimes I hear Claudia crying in her sleep. It's either because she's married to me or it's because of her mother. Sometimes when I wake her I think she's about to confess that it's both.  I didn't mean for that first sentence to sound dramatic. But before you can find passion, you have to live. You have to say, I WANT to live.  Life is very hard. We're born and a moment later, the connection to all of our happiness that we've ever experienced in the womb is cut by scissors. And then we are slapped hard by the doctor.  Wake up!  We're hit and slapped and burned by cigarettes all over our bodies over and over again until the day we die.  So there's got to be a reason we put up with all this punishment.  The first time I kissed a woman, I couldn't believe it. My lips touched the top of her lips, then the bottom of her pout. Then I found her, then I found me, and under a torn and desperate moon, I found a single moment of pleasure.  It was wonderful. But I wondered, is this where the passion is?  Because there are many of these moments, both good and bad, where inspiration might strike us.  But at some point, they all meld together. And 10 years out I look back and I say, "that seems like yesterday". The days are bolted together by a stapler called "routine".  What happened to those moments: my mom screaming my name though the neighborhood, my friends ignoring the parents, we were all on two or three piles of rocks on construction sites we were strictly forbidden from playing near.  We were throwing rocks at each other. Because one side was Saturn and the other side was Jupiter and they were at war. Occasionally one of us would time travel and teleport to the other side. And the rock throwing would go in a different direction. There's no north and south in space. And we were in space, with laughter and fun and energy teleporting us back and forth, rocks were our weapons of mass destruction, laughter was our reasons for being, for ignoring the screaming intensity by which one day tediously turns into the next.  "I hit him!"  Einstein found his passion because he wondered what a man traveling the speed of light on a spaceship if he looked out the window and saw a man standing still.  DaVinci found his passion drawing machines with wings that flapped like birds - the first illustrations of what 500 years later became planes. Just doodles. Thousands of them.  Charles Darwin found his passion playing with rocks halfway around the world. He played with them, he kicked them around, he drew pictures of the tree of life around those rocks, for EIGHT YEARS, before returning to the land of adults where he accomplished his life's work while all of the adults jeered in his path.  Mozart found his passion when he finally escaped the adulthood of a steady job in Salzburg, for the virility of Vienna where commanding operas and orchestras and singers and actors he grated Don Giovanni, the opera that changed every piece of music that ever came after that.  Marie Curie found her passion, like so many of us, by again playing with rocks. Why did some rocks seem to be like the sun, their own source of light when all else around them was pitch black dark.  Mick Jagger had no musical talent at all but would collect blues records from America and he and his childhood friend Keith Richards would lie around listening to them.  When his parents sent him off to study at the London School of Economics, he was still listening to those records and doodling the notes rather than paying attention to supply versus demand.  Mary Shelley wondered what it would be like if a machine had intelligence. She called her machine Frankenstein and made up stories about how people would treat such a hybrid human/machine.  Ada Lovelace wondered what it would be like to tell a machine what to do. Could such a machine ever exist?  Steve Jobs loved calligraphy and using electronics to scam the phone system.  Nobody discovered their passion as an adult. The child that still lives and breathes and is hidden inside all of us knows the secret of our passion.  Will this child tell us. Can we tease it to give us a clue? Will the child lead us on the right path or maybe play with us and show us the wrong directions first.  It doesn't matter. It's by following the child inside of us that we get closer to the treasure buried at the bottom of an infinitely deep ocean.  The ocean that is built from our responsibilities, our mortgages, our bosses, our schools, our governments, everything that puts a roadblock in between us and competence, us and our friends, us and our freedom.  I try to be a child. And when adulthood gets in the way, I cry. I get scared. I want the childhood back.  It's not easy. Because the world wants you to "act your age". So it becomes practice. It becomes exercise.  But here are ten ways I still try to be a child every day. And every day I find my passion. And every day I know I have to repeat these tricks to find that child inside of me:  - PLAY Every day I have to do something for no other reason at all than that it's fun. If I don't do it, the no fun.  What can you do that's fun? Play a game with someone else. Learn a magic trick. Sing.  When people want me to meet at their office I suggest the local ping pong establishment instead. It's through Play that we get to know each other. That  the children we left behind get to meet and together destroy the universe.  - FREE  Nobody paid Einstein to daydream about two people staring at each other, with one going through space as fast as he could.  In fact, he was a clerk in a patent office and could've stayed that way forever.  Nobody paid Ada Lovelace to imagine a world of computers 12o years before one existed. She was supposed to just be a stay-at-home Countess and enjoy her luxuries.  Every day I know I have to pay the bills to live. But I also have to do something totally free in order not to die.  The world of money is a tiny subset of the world of imagination.  - WHY? Why did the micro-cultures on one island look ever so slightly different than the micro-cultures that lived on the next? Darwin wondered.  Why did uranium give off light? Marie Curie wondered. She wondered about it until it killed her.  Why did Opera make Mozart tingle despite the acclaim he was receiving from the blander concertos popular at the time.  Why do children ask why and when you answer they ask why again, and then again.  When you take a subway in NYC it says "mind the gap".  It's in the gaps of adults talking that you have to catch yourself and ask "Why?"  "We just got divorced and then I moved to NYC," says one man to the other. "Why?" is what I always wonder. Why did you get divorced. Why did you pick NYC?  It's none of my business. But a kid doesn't care. A kid asks Why? The Whys add up. The Whys add up on the search for passion.  - FRIENDSHIPS A friend of mine is working on a TV show. I'm going to meet him later today to see how it's going.  To be honest, I want to write an episode for his TV show. Just for the fun of it. I have ideas for stories. It was my list of ten ideas each day this week.  It was fun. But most of all, I want to hear all the things he's learning by doing his TV show. And then I want to ask him about my own creative challenges.  Friendships challenge each other. First we throw rocks at each other. But those rocks ignite the imagination of Jupiter and Saturn and time travel.  Look at all of the arts and sciences: Steve Jobs started as friends with Steve Wozniak long before they made a dime.  Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg.  Jackson Pollack and Jasper Johns and Roy Lichtenstein and later Andy Warhol. The friendships that pushed each other to the next level. That pushed each other to compete and to play and to battle and to create.  To create! - INTERESTS Pierre and Marie Curie simply wanted to find out why a rock would glow. And then they fell in love and became adults.  Benjamin Franklin flew a kite to discover electricity.  Galileo was interested in finding out what would happen if a boulder and a feather flew off a tall building at the same time and then discovered the most useful scientific theories of all time.  - HOPES AND DREAMS When I was a little kid I had a notebook. It will filled with "David likes Lorie because I saw him look at her." and "Joanne likes Bobby because she laughed at his joke."  I wrote every day. I wrote a play about a moon that was a live. I wrote a story about Presidents. I wanted to write. I had dreams.  But dreams and mortgages have a hard time staying in the same head. It's ok to be worried about the mortgage. But don't forget to have a little bit of hope. And to see what happens if you act on that daydream, even if just a second.  - DRAWINGS AND DRUMS I asked for a drumset as a kid. But I never used it. But I did draw. I doodled all the time. I drew every day.  Adults say, "I can't draw."  Of course you can! Here's a crayon. Go! I bought a box of crayons (16 colors) the other day.  I just doodled. I colored things in. Some of the colors went outside the lines.  Just practice staying kid-like. Draw a face. I drew my wife. It looked nothing like her. So I turned her into a monster. It still looked nothing like her.  So I ripped up the drawing and started again. Like a kid.  - MOVEMENT When I was a kid I'd get home and jump on the bike (no helmet) and drove everywhere I could. I'd cross the highway! Hopefully my parents never saw me.  I ran up and down the street. We played football on the cement, throwing each other down.  Movement gets every neuron creating. Gets the body healthy. Gets the emotions roaring as you touch and tackle and daydream and breathe in the air with the sun burnt from the day about to die into a sunset.  - CONFUSION When I first moved to New York and I had my very first vacation, I had no money to go anywhere. I was stuck in the city. So I would walk around.  I wandered into areas I had never been before. I was confused where I was. I was confused why other people were out at 10 in the morning. Why weren't they at their jobs?  I wandered from confusion to confusion. Eventually, I started a project, "3am" trying to figure out why people were out at 3 in the morning on a Wednesday night. I was confused and wanted to know.  When I do a podcast and someone gives the stock answer they give in every other answer, I get confused. "But didn't you cry when that company failed?" I want to know. What did you do?  - SOCIAL INCOMPETENCE I try to learn how to small talk. But I'm not good at it. This is not a bad or good thing. I want to get better.  But sometimes at a party with everyone laughing and having gun I feel alone and isolated.  I try to figure my way out of that feeling of isolation. How can I have fun also?  --- All of these things brings me back to those moments, both good and bad, when I was a kid.  I practice being a kid. A kid laughs 300 times. An adult, on average...five.  Sometimes I can go a week without laughing. Responsibilties, fear, loneliness, anxiety, regret, can weigh me down.  I didn't have those as a kid. I try to laugh. I try to find things that make me align.  As an adult you have to practice being a kid, letting that child peek out again. He or she wants to come out and play and see the world again. What's changed?  The child wants to know! But guess what?  The adults know.  I have experience now. I've had the pills in the mouth. I've been divorced and lost two houses and lost a family.  I've lost my money and been scared and lost a business and had people hate me and try to ruin me.  I've had people I've loved betray me and reject me.  I've had successes that came from hard work and from 100 hour work weeks I thought I would never survive but I learned persistence and I learned how to make it work.  And I learned how to succeed and I learned how to survive failure. Some of the time.  Experience mixed with childhood is a roller coaster. Is a playground. You swing as high as possible and experience knows you will come down safe.  There's no one answer how to find your passion.  But every day, give the child inside of you some exercise using the 10 ideas above.  Mix that child with the experience you've learned over the years of fire and ice.  You'll find your passion. Your passion will find you.  And it's there, in that kiss of passion and you, in that kiss of your inner child and your outer adult, that you will find it.  In the middle its there, torn asunder but ready to be put together and to come out and play.

Too many of us believe in a magical being called ‘passion’. “If only I could find my passion”, we cry. “Finding my passion would make me happy”.   Well, passion is real, and very powerful. But almost everything people believe about finding it is wrong. Rule 1: Passion comes from success All of our emotions exist for good reason. We feel hunger to ensure we don’t starve. We feel full to ensure we don’t burst. And we feel passion to ensure we concentrate our efforts on things that reward us the most. Imagine you start a dance class. You find it easy. You realise you’re getting better than others, and fast. That rising excitement you feel is your passion, and that passion makes you come back for more, improving your skills, and compounding your strengths.  The enemy of passion is frustration. If you constantly struggle with something, you’ll never become passionate about it. You learn to avoid it entirely, guaranteeing you never improve.  Most people get this backwards. They think we discover our passion, and that makes us good at something. It’s actually finding that you’re good which comes first. Passion comes from success. Rule 2: Childhood is where passion goes to die In theory childhood provides a great opportunity to try a bit of everything, find your talents, and with them, your passions. But think for a moment how badly the system is stacked against you. Say school lets you try 20 subjects, ranking you against thousands of other children. Those aren’t good odds. Most kids are, by definition, around average. And it doesn’t matter how much we improve education, because people need to feel exceptional to feel passionate, and improving education simply moves up the average.   Say you’re one of the lucky ones, and you’re top of your junior math class. The education system will keep rising your difficulty until you find a level – like college – where you’re not exceptional anymore. Even if you actually are objectively pretty great, once you feel merely average, you’ll find your passion slipping. And that’s if you’re lucky. What if your passion was for art? From an early age that passion is compromised by its social consequences. “It’s hard to make a living from painting” say your parents. “Your cousin is doing so well from engineering. Why can’t you be more like him?” And so you put your passions to one side, and let them wither. In a population of billions, it’s obvious that not everyone can be unusually great at a handful of academic subjects. What if your true skills are in speechwriting, or creative dance, or making YouTube commentaries of videogames? None of those things are even on the syllabus. And so most people grow up without much passion for anything. Rule 3: Passion can be created It may help to know that the most successful people in life generally didn’t pick their passion off a shelf.   In fact, many of the world’s most successful people dropped out of education entirely. Not because they were stupid – but because they found other areas where they were more skilled that education did not recognise. They created their own passions. Only a tiny fraction of people can expect to excel in the narrow subjects that childhood primes us for. And competition in that space is basically ‘everybody in the world who went to school’, which doesn’t help our chances. But if you look outside of that space, you’ll find less competition, and more options. And this is how you tip the odds of finding a passion in your favour. Option 1: Create something When you create something new, you’re inventing something to be passionate about. You might design novelty cushions, or write Batman stories, or start a Twitter account dedicated to fact-checking politicians.  New things are relatively uncontested. By creating something new, you’ve made your odds of becoming exceptional far, far higher. Now it’s important to note that this doesn’t sidestep Rule #1: passion comes from success. So if your new Twitter account only has 5 followers after a year, you probably won’t be too passionate about it. If you had 5 million, you’d have quit your job. You must find success to fuel your passion.   But at least you’ve drastically improved your odds, because your competition is so limited. Only a handful of people will even dare to try something new. And you can be one of them, just by starting. You see this pattern throughout history’s greats. A student called Mark was never going to be the world’s greatest programmer. But he started building cool websites, and he found he was unusually good at this because even better programmers rarely dared to try. It just so happens one of his little experiments became Facebook. Option 2: Lead a new trend The older and more established an area is, the harder it will be to compete in. Millions have got there before you, and the lower your odds of standing out, the lower your odds of being passionate. But there’s always a new frontier being born, a place where everyone else is hopelessly incapable, and even modest skills can be impressive.   Say you were a teenager who started making YouTube videos, back in 2005. You grow a modest following, and your growing success excites you. By the time the ‘grown up’ world had realised YouTube was Kind-Of-A-Big-Deal with 4 billion views every single day, you’ve become a passionate master of an invaluable new craft. That isn’t fantasy. There are mountains of hugely successful YouTubers, and most started in the same way: before everybody else. It’s the same for the first bloggers, rappers, and videogame designers. If you can find something new that’s growing fast, and get skilled at it early, you’ll find it disproportionately easy to excel because of the lack of competition. And that’s your new passion right there. Option 3: Fuse mediocrity One limitation of education is it’s designed to narrow your skills. Education generally finds your One Best Thing, and pushes that thing as far as you can stand it:   The problem is most of us, by definition, can’t be the best in any one area. But we can be exceptional in our combinations. Say you’re an average artist, with a decent sense of humour. You won’t have much hope with an art degree, and you can’t study ‘humour’ as a subject. But you could be an awesome cartoonist. Or take an average business student, with some programming ability, and decent sales skills. That person is surprisingly well suited to become the boss of others who were better than them in any one of those areas. The most successful people are almost never defined by a single skill. They are a fusion of skills, often not even exceptional skills, but they’ve made their fusion exceptional. Steve Jobs was not the world’s greatest engineer, salesperson, designer or businessman. But he was uniquely good enough at all of these things, and wove them together into something far greater. This is the final route you have to finding your passion: combine skills into something more valuable. Remember, passion comes from success. If a new combination gets you better results, that could be your passion right there. Why passion matters Passion is attractive. As passion comes from believing you’re unusually good at something, being passionate is a very sincere way of saying, “by the way, I’m awesome”.   Passion will persuade people to follow you. It will persuade people to believe in you. But most importantly, passion will persuade yourself. Passion is an emotion specifically intended to make you go crazy and work your ass off at something because your brain believes it could rock your world. That, like love, is a feeling worth fighting for. And like love, what we’re passionate about is too important to leave to the mercy of fate. If you haven’t found your passion yet, create new things, lead new trends, and fuse new combinations. But don’t ever stop looking. More from me   .  Follow on Facebook   .  Follow on Twitter

Well, there is no such formula...but in fact you can listen to yourself before listening to any of those things told by people around you about you being passionate for something or the other. I will give you a practical way of finding this out.Sit for a while, take 4-5 deep breaths...then when you are peacefully relaxed,close your eyes...and ask the following question from within you and to you.. : If, FOR YOU,there was no hunger and responsibility in the world and you did not have to work or earn money to fill your belly...and then if you were to choose one thing out of all the activities happening in this world, considering the condition that-"no matter what you choose, you will be heavily and equally paid for it...", then what would be the first and foremost thing that you would choose..????You can scroll through all the things coming in your mind, discard those which you feel unworthy and then choose something that you are only and only INTERESTED IN from the thoughts you have had..!!..THAT IS YOUR PASSION..!!..Well, it may sound weird or even absurd...but then it works..!!We are never able to find the passion of our life because we are surrounded with lots of boundaries that put us in a closed state of mind and which only allow the mind to concentrate on those things. We become extremely busy and involved in fulfilling responsibilities, earning money, and doing all other chores that we are made to do just because we need to follow the pattern of living of a normal human being..!!Well,lost..??Let's take an example....A guys loves wildlife, and whenever he visits such a place, he loves capturing them. But then, back at his home, he is a software engineer, sits for a 9-6 job in his office chair, comes home, takes dinner and by end of year waits for a hike or a promotion..!!..Well, of course he can become passionate while doing his work so that he gives outstanding results to get his promotions. But then HIS OWN PASSION is no where around here.Had he been a wildlife photographer for real, he would smile at the end of the day while browsing through his pictures; would become more curious about more wildlife areas in the world; would have a deep sound satisfying sleep every night he comes from the forest, and soo on..!! :)So to find your passion, you need to to keep your circle of influence away from you and then look thought the PURE-YOU...!!.Have a nice time finding your passion and working upon it happily and contented :)Keep Smiling :)

In short: Seek. Try. Repeat as needed Elaborating on this… Learn as much as you can about yourself, including your personality, interests and character. The aim in this step is to discover (I) what are your values (ii) what is your personality (iii) what are your talents. Read self help books, psychology books, philosophy books, see a career counsellor etc… It's very important to understand what you enjoy and why you enjoy certain activities, and why you are drawn to do certain things. For example, you might enjoy music because it reminds you of a very pleasant memory during childhood. This is a good reason to pursue music in some form. Alternatively, you might want to be a doctor because of a subconscious sense of inferiority and needing to prove your self worth. This would not be a healthy reason to become a doctor because you might realise what you are doing later in life when it's too late to go back and pursue your true interests. What you learn in this step is important for the following steps and for you to understand whether certain activities that you might want to pursue as your passion may or may not be suitable (because they might not suit your personality / character, or you might not be pursuing them for the right reasons).Make a list of your talents, and then find activities that include your talents. The reason is that, usually, passion is not something we are born to do - it's something we learn to love. (proof: If you were born to do it, you wouldn't ask this question). So, try as many activities as you can. E.g. If your talent is playing guitar, try playing in a band, playing solo, playing small gigs in bars, playing on your own, recording some songs, upload them to YouTube etc… Once you've done that, now you can try honing in to one or two activities. Say you like playing in a band, trying doing it and sustaining it for at least a few months. Do you eventually get super sick of it? If so, let it go and move on to the next talent/list of activities.Find the activities that you “just want to do” even if the world is ending. I've come to this realisation quite recently, for obvious reasons. I'll give my own life example because I have made so many mistakes and wasted so much time, I hope you can learn from my mistakes. I am a nurse presently, but I enjoy physics and I enjoy teaching. But I've never truly pursued either with full steam. I've felt teaching and nursing are “too simple” and that I'm “not doing anything big”. So I now want to get into policy analysis, thinking I'll do something big. But after many years of painful self reflection, I've come to realise that I might just want to “accomplish something big” to compensate for my depression, and to compensate for the thoughts of worthlessness. With the bushfires and the coronavirus, with the world feeling like it's falling apart, I'm slowly starting to realise that I don't need to be anything big, i just want to curl up with a book on general relativity and my family and that's it. Simple dreams, yes, but I enjoy it, for no real reason except I enjoy it. THAT is what you need to look for. Proof: Jobs, Wosniak, Gates, Musk, Bezos, Einstein, Feynman, Dirac etc…what is the most fundamental thing that they all have in common? They loved what they do/did.Develop your focus and discipline to get through the boring days. No matter how passionate you are, there will always be those boring, grinding days. The question is: are you able to get through those days? I used to think that people who are obsessed with something or “truly passionate” won't ever have those days. I think I was wrong. I think it's more that they have such strong character and discipline that they ram through such obstacles as if they weren't even there. They are ultra focused on their goals that they don't care how laborious the work is for a day or a few weeks or months; they just get it done. You will need this step to do the next.Set short term and long term goals, and undertake responsibility: I think a large part of a passion is accomplishing something, and being competent enough that you can bear responsibility. Say you are have discovered your talent is caring for people, so you get in to nursing. So you get into it, work hard and diligently, gain experience and obtain promotions, and eventually become so respected by your peers and bosses that you are given lots of responsibility - THAT'S the moment you start going to work thinking “Gosh I love what I do”.And here are a few extra tips while you are still searching for your passion: Stop making plans. My big mistake in life is thinking I can plan my life. That’s wrong. Set an overall outline with goals along the way, but not a firm year-by-year plan. Because life has an interesting way of changing things up. Also, living in this frame of mind where you can “plan to have a passion” is plain ridiculous. We don't know why exactly we like the things we do, so stop planning to like something.Try. It is imperative that you actually try to do whatever you want to do. And give it a good solid try, not just a few seconds.Your passion may not be your job, and that's okay. In this world, it is very difficult to have a passion that is also a job. We hear alot about the success stories, but not the many many unsuccessful stories. But that's okay. Find a job to feed your stomach, and find your passion to feed your soul.Avoid regret, not mistakes. Another failing of mine; I was so afraid of making mistakes, that I made regrets. And these have stuck with me 😔. I wish you do not do this. Make mistakes. Fail. And move on. Basically when you are faced with a decision, think, “will I regret not doing this”.I wish you all the best, and I hope you have a great life devoid of fear and regret.

Read the book “So good they cant ignore you” by Cal Newport, or blinkist has a 24hr free trial(just 24hrs? Really blinkist?) Where they give you only highlights of the book. The thing is, your passions can change, and they can be great but not lead to any job you get up in the morning every day excited to go to(I like my job personally and you’ll never have 100% days like that), but if you solely focus on passion you may end up going from job to job, searching, instead of focusing on rare and valuable skills. Master a valuable skill and you may find passion for it down the road. Or worst case scenario, that skill mastery can lead to allowing your passion to be a great little hobby on the side. By the way, mastering skills does not mean you must pursue a regular job, you can certainly use that for self-employment, but if you don’t develope useful and important skills, you won’t be in business very long. I’m 23 man, I enjoy the life I’ve created so far regardless of the human faults that naturally exist. I used to be searching for my passion all the time, and what this led me to was very hot, and very cold approaches to the same topic in only a matter of months. Meaning I’d be super into something, only to drop it for the next shiny object months later. Passion won’t necessarily lead to financial success(it could though), but passion can lead to fun, community, friendship, challenge, and other healthy aspects of life. Passion misused can easily lead to anger, frustration, violence, and most likely, social media arguments. Finding your passion, in my opinion leads to the same cliché response garnered when asking “How can I find the love of my life?” It will find you when you aren’t searching for it. So focus on what you can control in the mean time, which can be learning more about yourself, building discipline, developing valuable skills, learning how to feel and understand emotions, while also not allowing them to control you, ie. a level of detachment from emotions. You can learn to take care of yourself, and learn to know your needs. You can stop externalizing things like support, happiness, comfort, confidence. And learn to build those things from within.

Spend some alone time every day, even 20 minutes before bed, and think about what has interested you in that day and in the recent past.Some may call it "meditating", thinking, etc., but I think it is mostly about getting to know yourself. I have always regarded "thinking/meditating" as a process of "reading/analyzing your mind", which in turn leads to discovering your true passion. I am also in my 20's and I have always thought that our generation never really appreciates time spent alone. Rather, most of us decide to spend time posting nonsense on SNS and spend hours every day, reading through shallow posts other peers have written. Some of my own passion rooted from my love of cars. Back in my freshman year in college, with an intended major in business, I was pressured to join a business fraternity just because it increased my chances of getting in the business school. Even then, I was wise enough to know that the fundamental concepts of "business" and "fraternity" don't go together and I especially didn't want to pretend like I'm a "bro" to some superficial and opportunistic brats. So instead, I dropped my chances of getting into the business school, declared economics as my major (bleh!), and spent my spare time pursuing my personal interests.I started by reading posts on a small forum and doing some DIY modifications on my Camaro that I got for my 19th birthday.  I took my car apart in my apartment's garage, installed a new set of speakers, and changed the mufflers as well. While these tasks seem very simple, I learned a lot and my curious brain was feeding quite well. Then I began to read news and magazines about car trends, and spent a lot of time thinking about near-future trends.Then, I began to wonder about the automobile software, and thought that it has a lot of room for improvement. Thus, I got into studying computer programming and software development and it was a lot of fun!Nowadays, I am combining my interests (connecting the dots, I would say) and have begun studying about the Business-IT hybrid industry (aka Big Data, Business Intelligence Analytic, etc.). After amassing all that knowledge from studying near-future trends, economics, and computer science, my level of understanding of seemingly new concepts in the BI field has been progressively faster, and it would take me just two days to read over an intermediate-level reading (400+ pages) on BI, without leaving out big concepts (skipping some minor ones though). More likely than not, you are very close from finding your passion. Don't be afraid to discover and admit your fields of interest and explore them in depth. Don't be discouraged by all the achievements that peers around you are making, because many times, such emotions will blind you from discovering your true passion.Most importantly, don't be a follower of others and be a conqueror of self. In my opinion, all it takes is 20 minutes a day to think over your days. Your true passion is not found overnight, but is realized through series of discoveries of small interests. "Life is a Marathon, not a sprint".It's like you can't beat a train on a rail that constantly goes 40 mph, by driving 95 mph in an automobile on a road with stop signs every 10 blocks or so. You may feel good about yourself while driving that fast, but in time, the train will beat you by far. Life is not a race but a journey. 20 minutes a day!

The best advice I can give to you is that you will never find your passion just by sitting around. A lot of people just wait for their passion to come to them, but you need to search for it by taking action. Here's my story: I came into college as an astronautical engineering major. I have always loved science and one night when I was in the southern coast of France in a small town called La Ciotat, I saw the milky way for the first time. This moment inspired me to do something space related which in turn led me to write the essay that got into my dream college in Los Angeles. However, after one semester I realized how tough the competition was in my field and that many career paths led to military and defense. Help create technology that the military could use to harm others? Hells no. So that only really meant one option at the time: NASA. I asked my professor who had previous worked at NASA what I should do to increase my chances to work there, and he told me that becoming an Industrial Engineer might be the best solution.  After I switched majors to Industrial Engineering, I discovered that I found it extremely boring. The curriculum at my school made the major appear as a glorified supply chain worker. I wanted to change the world, and doing what I was learning in class did not seem to be my calling. It was at that time I started reading. I read a lot of things that inspired me to do something big and one of these readings happened to be TechCrunch. One day I noticed an ad on the TechCrunch website asking for volunteers for their first conference called TechCrunch Disrupt. I said, "why not?" because it seems pretty interesting since I had never been to any kind of conference before. It was at this conference where I can say I found my passion. It was here I met brilliant people from all over America and it was at this conference I first witnessed a hackathon. It was intense, it was crazy, and it was eye opening. I always had ideas, but to see people make something out of nothing in just 24 hours showed me that through hard work and perseverance, anything is possible. These hackers became my heroes. Every year since freshman year I have tried so hard to become a programmer and create products for a career. Every year though, my search always led me to something else. My freshman year I was hired to Avis Budget Group as an IT/Marketing intern because my interviewer and I talked about the future of HTML5 and flash for 45 minutes. My sophomore year I was hired as an IT intern at Johnson & Johnson because my interviewer and I talked about how awesome Google I/O was which I had the honor to attend at the time. My junior year I worked at KPMG as a management consultant (because I burned out a little on computer science at the time and noticed this when one night I drunkenly said to a girl, "I can't talk to you because you don't know HTML"). At the beginning of this year I got the opportunity to work at SpaceX, but I soon realized that my passion was no longer in space. But during all this time, during all these detours, I always continued to code. I took part in Linkedin's Intern Hackathon, I built websites on my own, I read thousand page books on different coding languages in days. I even threw my own hackathon at USC to share my passion with future Trojans. I would have never guessed that I would be hired to Salesforce.com at the end of my college career to build prototypes coming out with an Industrial Engineering degree. In fact, none of my friends did. I never sat around. I stayed awake countless nights trying to figure out how PHP worked instead of studying for my quizes for class, I drove 5 hours straight just so I could stay awake for 24 more hours to code with people I've never met before, but most importantly I never stopped being passionate. It takes some effort to find your passion, but when you do, pursuing it feels easy as hell.

This is going to be a long answer as it comes from someone who is pursuing his ‘Passion’. And it might make you feel uncomfortable and it might shake your belief in various theories like the one Oliver Emberton has nicely described. I also know that you are just 24 and patience isn’t your greatest virtue, but then, this is important and you know that. So stay with me.  First of all let us ask ourselves this basic question - What is Passion? Passion is something that we really want to do, no matter what others say, no matter what we get out of it, and no matter what the results are. I mention these three things because let's say if your parents or your lover are not in agreement with your passion, you cannot give up on your passion. Similarly, passion is something that is not result oriented, though success is (this is where I disagree with Oliver Emberton that passion needs success). So many great people we know today who were not considered that ‘great’ in their era. They did not make much of money or get many rewards. But still they have made so much contribution that none of us can ignore.  So, we come to the first rule to find your passion - you will have to forget the results. You have to do it no matter what others say, no matter what you get out of it.  Now that we know what passion is, let us move forward and see how we can discover our passion. Or we can first go through a few questions that are important in this context. I am sure you will also have one (or more) of them in mind. What if I do not love anything enough to call it passion? I have interest in two-three areas. How do I figure out which one is my passion? I do not love my job. Can I quit it by saying – this is the call of my passion? Is it bad if I do not believe in passion? Why do I have to find my passion?  However irrelevant it might appear, but the last question is really very important.  WHY? Possible explanations are: Because you will die without passion: WRONGBecause happiness depends on passion: WRONGBecause the term ‘Passion’ has become so fashionable in the recent times that everybody just wants to have it: DAMN! YOU ARE A GENIUS Yes, I do believe that ‘Passion’ is one of the most overrated things in today’s world. In today’s world where we live – it is more connected than it had ever been before, we are awed by the success of others. We hear so many stories of success and passion that we also want to do something extraordinary to make our life worth.  In this situation we feel obliged (and pressurized) to find our passion. Fortunately, the earlier generations were quite ignorant about this idea.  That is my theory. And similarly, you will have many more theories. But if any theory was accurate, wouldn’t all of us be chasing our passion?  The reason why most of us never find our passion is that we keep thinking about success all the time. But think about this:  Is success really that important? It might disappoint you my dear friend, but the answer is no. And the answer lies in the fact that most of us have this craving of discovering our passion in twenties only. Ever wondered why? Not because we are young and brave but because we think that success is the only thing that can give us happiness. Which of course is not true.  Long story short, if you want to find your passion, think of life as an opportunity to make a contribution not a ladder to climb the success. The point is – don’t think about ‘Passion’ but think about your life. And if you REALLY REALLY want to do something ‘big’ in life, let me make things easy for you with following points: ·       The biggest mistake that we make while discovering our passion is that we seek the answer it outside, when the answer lies within. We all know what we want to do but we are just afraid to pursue it. So what we do we start chasing success, so that we can convince ourselves and everyone that we have enough and we can really do whatever we want. Think about it – what would you do if you have got all the money  and success in the world. Would you still do the same job? In most cases, the answer is ‘No’. We need to conquer our own fears and start believing ourselves that we can do it. Then only we will be the right path.·       There is a big confusion in – becoming something and doing something. ‘Becoming something’ is what depends on circumstances, market, and other external factors. ‘Doing something’ is totally up to you. I have seen so many people who want to become politicians so that they can serve people. But if they really wanted to serve people, they could have started with it in the first place. They don’t need to become something for that. This applies for every profession. So, passion is (and should be) about doing not becoming. Let’s say if you love playing Cricket. Playing Cricket for your country can be your dream, but that cannot be a passion. Make sure that you enjoy your work so much that the results do not affect your love for that.·       Have you ever seen a person who is pursuing his or her passion by following a tried and tested theory and eliminating the options which are not working out. No right? There cannot be. The essential ingredient to find your passion is – to struggle. This might sound crazy, but if you do a quick research, you will find that no sober person in his/her comfort zone ever found their passion. You cannot give up on your passion. If you are going for it with a back up option, there are 100 percent chances that you will go back to your back up plan. So, ask yourself what is your passion? What do you want to do more than anything else in the world? And then just go for it. Don’t stop, ever.·       Now, the most important point. Many people might become successful and fool themselves by saying that they are pursuing they have found their passion. But you know that is not true. In fact success is the biggest hurdle to discover your passion. When we get enough money and fame, we often forget this important question – is this really we want to do?  And as I said, your heart already knows the answer. It always does… Be honest with yourself and you will find it. Because if it cannot, no one or nothing else can… Before I say good bye, let me write something for you. I hope you will keep it with you.  Don’t ask me, don’t ask others,Your heart already knows the answer. There will be fear, the path will never be clear, but... Your heart already knows the answer.Fall, fail, and fly, don’t be afraidYour heart already knows the answer.Life is short, short enough to not do everything,But your heart already knows the answer.  Coming to my journey, yes, I have identified my passion. I love writing and this is what I want to do, no matter what I get in return, what others say about it or what the results turn out to be. Because, once (and just once) I talked honestly with myself – and my heart knew the answer.

Question this to yourself ?  WHAT IS YOUR TENNIS BALL? This question, derived from a terrific commencement speech given at MIT last year by Dropbox founder Drew Houston, is a good place to start because it cuts to the chase. As Houston explained, "The most successful people are obsessed with solving an important problem, something that matters to them. They remind me of a dog chasing a tennis ball." To increase your chances of happiness and success, Houston said, you must "find your tennis ball—the thing that pulls you." Sometimes, we may not be aware of what truly engages us until we examine our own activities and behaviors from a detached, inquisitive perspective. "You almost have to ask yourself, What do I find myself doing?," explains the author and happiness guru Gretchen Rubin. "What you spend time doing can also tell you what you should do. Because sometimes the things we do without thinking really are things we naturally enjoy or are good at." So pay attention to what pulls you. For instance, "when you’re in a bookstore," says author Carol Adrienne, "what section of the store are you drawn to?" That will not only tell you what books you love—it may point to where your tennis ball can be found. For a slightly different spin on the "tennis ball" concept, ask: What am I doing when I feel most beautiful? This is about identifying not only what draws you in, but also what makes you shine. Jacqueline Novogratz, founder of The Acumen Fund, told me that in her globe-spanning travels she often asks people this question, sometimes in unlikely settings. She once posed the question to women living in a slum in Bombay. At first, "one woman said, ‘There’s nothing in our lives that’s beautiful,’" Novogratz says. "But eventually, a woman who worked as a gardener said, ‘All winter long I slog and slog, but when those flowers push through the ground, I feel beautiful.’" Novogratz says it’s important to think about "that time and place where you feel most alive—whether it’s when you’re solving a problem, creating, connecting with someone, traveling." Whatever it is, Novogratz says, identify it—and if possible, find a way to do more of it. (A different version of Novogratz’s "beautiful" question is suggested by consultant Keith Yamashita of SY Partners: "Who have you been, when you’ve been at your best?") What is something you believe that almost nobody agrees with you on? This question, which PayPal co-founder and Thiel Foundation chief Peter Thiel has shared publicly in interviews and lectures, is designed to do two things: help you figure out what you care about and also determine whether it’s worth pursuing, based on uniqueness. Thiel concedes that it’s a challenging question because it can be tough to find an idea or belief that isn’t shared by many others. "Originality is deceptively hard," he told Pandodaily.  But if you can find a problem or challenge no one else is tackling, you can carve your own niche and create value. "You don’t want to be interchangeably competing with people," Thiel says. Though we’re taught to do what others are doing and try to succeed by out-competing, this, in Thiel’s view, amounts to "beating your head against the wall—rather than going through the open door that no one is looking at." What are your superpowers? The idea behind this question from Yamashita is to "unpack the combination of personality traits and aptitudes you bring effortlessly to any situation." The filmmaker Tiffany Shlain of The Moxie Institute also explores strengths and natural "superpowers" in her new web film "The Science of Character," which suggests that if we can identify our inherent character strengths and build on them, we can lead happier, more successful lives. Having trouble listing your powers and strengths? Check out the "Periodic Table of Character Strengths" in Shlain’s film, or refer to Gallup executive Tom Rath’s popular "StrengthsFinder 2.0" program, with its menu of 34 traits. Once you’ve identified your own strengths, you’ll be in a better position to make the most of what you already have going for you. Sometimes by looking back into the past, says Rubin, you can get a glimpse of who you really are and what you loved doing before others started telling you what you should do. So what did you enjoy doing at age 10? Eric Maisel, a psychotherapist and author, agrees, adding: "The things we loved as a child are probably still the things we love." He suggests drawing up a list of favorite activities and interests from childhood—"and see what still resonates with you today. And then it’s a process of updating those loves. You may have loved something that doesn’t even exist now, or doesn’t make sense in your life now—but you may be able to find a new version of that." What are you willing to try now? One of the best ways to find your purpose and passion is through experimentation. For many people, this is counter-intuitive. Herminia Ibarra, a professor at INSEAD and author of Working Identity: Unconventional Strategies for Reinventing Your Career, points out that there is a tendency to devote extensive time, research, and planning to figuring out the ideal path before taking any action. This may involve poring over self-help books, soliciting advice, and waiting for the epiphany that shows you your "true self"—at which point you can strike out confidently in a new direction. We learn who we are—in practice, not in theory—by testing reality. But that’s all wrong, according to Ibarra. "To launch ourselves anew, we need to get out of our heads," she says. "We need to act." That means devising a series of trials and errors: Ibarra advises looking for temporary assignments, outside contracts, advisory work, and moonlighting to get experience or build skills in new industries; executive programs, sabbaticals, and extended vacations also can be valuable in providing opportunities to experiment. She concludes, "We learn who we are—in practice, not in theory—by testing reality." Looking back on your career, 20 or 30 years from now, what do you want to say you’ve accomplished? In an interview, LinkedIn CEO Jeff Weiner said that he often asks prospective employees the above question. "You’d be amazed how many people I meet who don’t have the answer to the question," Weiner said. So here’s your chance to answer it (without the pressure of having Weiner across the table, awaiting your response). Think of this exercise as a less-gloomy version of write-your-own-obit. What would you include on your list of hoped-for achievements? Or, even better than compiling a laundry list, why not figure out…

The key to loving your job is to ask yourself one simple question: “What is my biggest strength?” Think about it: so many people are in jobs they hate because they haven’t found that one true passion. They are good at a few things so that’s what they do here and there, but they aren’t sure what that one big thing they want to do forever could be. Here is my message: stop doing shit you hate. Nail down your strengths so you can discover your passion. I have four steps to help you guys figure it out that will hopefully help all the comments and emails I see around “how do I find my strengths?” or “how I do I know what my best job skills are?” There are so many articles that dance around, but I want to give you all four concrete pieces of advice. #1: WHAT ARE MY SKILLS? Take the five to ten people that know you the best. Split them into two categories: people you connect with on a deep level of love, and people who you are close with, but maybe you’re a little different in lifestyle and personality. Then, ask one person from each category to honestly tell you what they think you’re best at, and what they think you’re worst at. “What are my skills and abilities, and what are my weaknesses?” I truly believe that collecting market research and creating an atmosphere that allows someone to be honest with you are the two big things here. When someone really loves you, they might not want to be totally honest, because they don’t want to hurt you. But the quickest way to find your strengths is by eliminating weaknesses. #2: WHAT ARE MY STRENGTHS? You can’t take a romantic view on the skills that have made you successful so far in life. For example, you might have been a straight A student even though you have no passion for academics. Or you’re naturally amazing at basketball, but that isn’t what you truly want to pursue. But one way those strengths can come in handy tremendously is by using them as a blueprint to discovering talents you may not have understood before. Maybe you’ve been blinded by the overarching strength itself because you aren’t passionate about it, but list all the things that that skill requires you to do. Don’t take them for granted. There are many things that go into being good at something. Your potential doesn’t end with that one skill. #3: READ EVERYTHING Now, I know this is a very grey world. To find your personal strengths is, well, very personal. But I want to make sure I leave you with real actionable advice. So here is a super specific one for you: go on a vacation. Yeah, seriously. But it’s not a total vacation. During that time, you’re going to go back through every email, letter or note someone wrote you, talking about your accolades or failures. Read all of them. And as you read, ask yourself “Which of my skills am I consistently praised for?” And on the flipside: what do people continuously say you are bad at? This task could take many many hours. You might be thinking it will take too many hours. But think: you are the one who clicked on this article. It can’t be that much time because it seems like you really want to figure this out, right? In the end, it’s a small amount of time to sacrifice compared to the happiness it will give you for the rest of your life. #4: ASK STRANGERS On social media, make a video or post asking everyone who follows you the very question we have been repeating over and over: “What are my personal strengths?” This can be phrased in a number of ways when it comes to people who follow you for your content and comments. I like to ask what I am doing that they like. What have they found helpful? What has my best work been? What is my potential? This is now the widest net you can cast to get the information. Because these are people who have been viewing you from a very specific place, your social media personality, you are able to curate that part of your life as well into the decision of which strength to pursue. After these four steps, you should have the depth of personal information you need to move forward to your new destination. Bring all these thoughts together to find the skill and strength that will benefit you. From there, the options are endless: a new career move? Start a new company? Find a business partner that complements your strengths and work for him? Start a company with him? I’m pumped for you just thinking about the awesome stuff you can do.

Jeff Bezos was asked how he became so passionate. Most expected a reply long & sour, but Bezos kept it short & sweet: “You don’t choose your passions. Your passions CHOOSE YOU.”  HOW TO LET YOUR PASSION CHOOSE YOU  I. YOUR DREAM is CALLING YOU . . . PICK UP!  Before he starred in the role as rapper "Jay-Z," became a billionaire and married Beyoncé, Shawn Carter was just one of the guys in the hood. … In Brooklyn, Carter was the gangly dude seen around town "walking down the street eating a $1 slice of pizza." Carter—a high school dropout—found himself in the unwanted position of street pharmacist. It was in the midst of petty drug-dealing, however, that Carter’s dream came calling. In an interview with Oprah, Carter recalled: I use to stand outside the bodega, and my mind would be overflowed with these poems . . . ya know. It got to a point where I’d have to rush inside the store to borrow a pen and brown paper bag to scribble on. It was like something was chasing me . . . trying to motivate me to do something more with my life. Eventually Carter answered the call from his dream to such an extent that the passion propelled him to become Jay-Z! Indeed: you don’t choose your passion, your passion chooses you. …  In 1990 Jeff Bezos had a comfortable position at the hedge fund D.E. Shaw & C0. At just 30, Bezos was making well into 6 figures and on his way to a comfortable lifestyle. Yet friends and family were shocked when Bezos randomly quit his secure, well-paying job to start Amazon. And what was Bezos’ response? “You don’t choose your passions. Your passions choose you!”   II. WHAT EINSTEIN KNEW ABOUT HOW “GENIUS” ties into PASSION When you see the name Albert Einstein, you’re literally seeing the nickname for GENIUS. Notice that listed among the synonyms for genius is one rather “peculiar” addition.  Think about that for a second. … Indeed, it borders on unbelievable that the last name of an actual flesh and blood person serves as a nickname for Genius. Listed along with the usual suspects—brilliance, mastermind, etc—all of which are abstract nouns, there’s one name that stands out like Shaquille O'neal in a room of gymnasts.  And so, given that Einstein was genius personified, wouldn’t you suppose he knew a thing or two about uncovering the source of your passion? Here lies the reason Einstein went so far as to have said:  Bingo! Long before the word genius got distorted, it had a far simpler meaning. In fact, the original meaning of genius is Latin: “attendant spirit present from one's birth, innate ability or inclination [aka, passion].” Bingo! According to the ancient Romans, then, each person comes into the world stamped with a genius! In the Vedic tradition, this ancient wisdom is known as one’s dharma (धर्म). To put it simply: so far as each man, woman and child is an individual—which simply means UNIQUE—as a consequence each individual has the capacity to do ONE thing in a special way.   III. In CLOSING The Delphic Oracle called Socrates “the wisest person in Athens.” Socrates in turn justified the crowning by noting:  Take one glance at the definition of passion and its DNA becomes clear:  Passion = Boundless Enthusiasm. Bingo! Apply the Socratic method to the term enthusiasm, and the source from which your passion springs becomes apparent:  Passion/Enthusiasm (“possessed by a god”) and genius (“tutelary spirit present from one’s birth”). Btw: “god” and “spirit,” in this sense, means metaphysical—i.e., meta- (‘before’) + physical. … Hence the expression—PREsent (pre + sent) from one’s birth. And so, guess what? All point to the same source:  Bingo! Now you know why ol’ Bezos said the passion chooses you. … Now you know why ol’ Einstein said everyone has genius potential. … Let’s again make use of the Socratic Method. What exactly does INDIVIDUALITY mean?  Bingo! By definition: INDIVIDUAL = YOU are distinguished from all others (every other person, place and thing). Now you know why those Ancient Greeks were so darn obsessed with:  Ponder, if you will, this world’s stage was setup billions of years before you finally made your grand appearance. And, what may be even grander than the appearance itself is, well . . . get this: this is the only time in history that you—the INDIVIDUAL expression—will ever exist. … Ever! What does all this mean, you must wonder? In other words, just as your complete genetic instructions lay in your genes, so too did your passion and genius potential.  In other words: Genius + Passion = INDIVIDUALITY. Even the world’s most famous doctor never to have been awarded a PhD knew Passion speaks in the voice of individuality:  To put it simply: Whatever distinguishes you from others . . . Whether it be you’re naturally funny . . . Or you naturally sing with a voice so lovely even the hummingbirds stop chirping just to hear you perform live in the shower . . . Or you naturally argue so well that folks are convinced “ya should’ve been a lawyer” . . . In ever such case: your individuality, which daily seeks expression, is the voice of your PASSION calling out to you! Will you answer the call? What’s your hobby? If money were no object, what would you do for a living? In other words:  In short, whatever makes you, YOU—namely, the expression of your individuality—is the very voice of your passion. … Why else would you suppose someone like Lady Gaga wears a meat dress to the awards show? Or Michael Jackson donned a single glittery glove on one hand and held Bubbles the Chimp in the other?  Every such attempt to be like another comes at the price of compromising the expression of your own distinct genius . . . Each attempt to ignore being true to yourself comes at the price of ignoring the call from your own passion. … In short: learn to be indifferent to a world in which you are different!     DOG fo DNIM ehT

The fact that you asked this question shows that you are interested in finding something to which you wish to commit some of your time. A true passion can be inside you and still be undiscovered. Have you taken the time to think seriously about this topic? Please do so by asking yourself, "If everything was ideal in my life five or ten years from now, how would I know it? What would be happening?" Make a list of what an ideal life would look like. Do not judge your answers until you have exhausted the list. Keep pushing the question. Some of your answers may appear minor such as, "I would have ice cream whenever I wanted it." Do not worry about that. At this stage no answer large or small is right or wrong. Just keep going. List at least fifty items or activities. When you see what you perceive to be the components of your ideal life, ask yourself, "To what end?" Unless you are depressed, in which case you probably would not even attempt this exercise, one or more concepts will start to appear. It is possible you may derive your passion in this way. As a young man recently graduated from university with less than a stellar GPA, I did not know what I could do well for my life's work. I could get into a lower level law school, and perhaps join my father's law firm, but at that time the law was not of real interest as a life's work. So, I asked my father his opinion of what I could do and be happy/passionate about. He took off his glasses and told me that in his opinion there were many jobs available to me. The key was helping other people in some capacity. He had observed that I was most excited when I was doing something to make someone's life better in some way. Wham! He was right and I realized it. So, I became an educator. More or less, forty years of having the opportunity to help others help themselves was a joy!  That's my story, now go and find yours. Best of luck.

Ask yourself this simple question: “What would I do my entire life if there was no such thing as money?”. Would you be an artist ? Would you spend working out all day and being fit ? Would you spend your days cycling on a bike ? Would you spend the entire day in front of the computer writing code ? Imagine for a while that there is no such thing as money. What would you do to spend your time in that case? As money is completely out of the equation, you will only think of doing things that you absolutely love to do i.e the things you are passionate about. Now you might think of things like laying on bed all day, eating and chatting with friends. However, you might do that for a while and would eventually be fed up of it as these activities keep your mind relaxed. My question is, what would you do to keep your mind engaged in a healthy way? What is something which you would enjoy doing, even if it’s challenging and gives you a sense of accomplishment when you make progress ? Once you can answer this question, you have found your passion. Why most people cant correctly figure out their passion? A guy wanted to be an artist, according to him he was passionate about art. He imagined him selves to be a great artist who has his paintings in the worlds top art galleries and he being applauded by the crowd for his work. However, this is not what true passion is. The above guy is not passionate about art, he just craves to be a successful artist. This is where most people go wrong. A person can be said as truly passionate about art if he/ she enjoys the process of creating an art and does not care about the outcome at all. One who forgets to eat, sleep and drink just because they are so engaged in making an art. This is what true passion is. If you like wearing plush suits, drive a BMW and sit in a corporate office does not mean you have the passion for business. It’s when you like marketing, love making new products/services, love taking care of your customers more than anything else then this is what is called as having a true passion for business. Passion is something when you enjoy doing something so much that you hardly care about the end result.

I love this question... but I hate the top answer. I totally get what this person is saying and I respect their right to say it..but I firmly disagree. Identifying and living your passions gives meaning to life. How do you discover your passion? You work it. Throwing your hands up and quitting is definitely an option... it's just a very risky one. Personally, I don't want to wake up one day and have regrets. Despite how difficult this pursuit is, there's good news: You don't become passionate. You discover your passions.There are systematic ways to approach finding your passion.You're not alone - in fact, most people I know wrestle with this.  Here are some systematic tools and frameworks I've found helpful: 1) Focus on Progress: It depends on your situation, but can you carve out some time every day to devote to discovering your passion? Inaction - while a feasible strategy - is not advisable...unless you want to wake up in 20 years and realize how unhappy you are.. [insert sad-face here]. 2) Start with Everything: Find a list of sectors and cross out the ones that you aren't interested in. Which question is easier to answer:  A) What's your passion in life?
