response.answer_text: My biggest passion failed. Had I pursued my first passion, my life would be very different, potentially much worse than where I actually ended up. My second passion drove me to become a millionaire and retiree at age 28. Now, as a entrepreneur, my second passion has entirely replaced my first passion in life. I’m grateful I can share and utilize my skills to inspire others to access the same opportunities I had to reach financial freedom at a young age. I can say with 99% definitiveness that my second passion is actually my real calling, my purpose, and my primary identity, as it turned out. Here are a few lessons I learned about Passion along the way: #1. Your passions, while deeply meaningful, may not make sense practically. My first passion in life was (and still is) singing. I had been winning awards and contests since I was 14. I truly thought I had the core talent, early in life to make a living out of singing. My strategy was to utilize my fluent English skills and ride the increasingly popular Americanization wave just developing at that point in the Chinese Mandarin market. However, my mom (as you can imagine most Chinese immigrant parents) was staunchly against encouraging my dreams. At a young age, I was constantly belittled and chastised by my mother in her efforts to dissuade me from pursuing Chinese pop-stardom as a career. She would taunt me about how everyone was better than me and I’d never amount to anything as a singer. Since I wasn’t born from wealth, my mom saw the odds from afar, much clearer than I could. I was enraptured in my dreams and could see nothing other than the glory of my inevitable success. She knew for someone like me who was not professionally trained and possessed average looks could only go so far in the media industry, which is a grueling and less glamorous industry than it seems. My mom couldn’t financially afford to support my passion nor give me an advantage over others. Therefore, she tried her best to shield me from my passion in an effort to protect me against this threat to my future. #2. Sometimes, passions can hurt you more than help you. My dream and passion of singing died a slow and painful death. I refused to take my mom’s advice and staunchly decided to pursue my talents. For people who have multiple talents, whether that’s athletic, within the arts, or in any other specialism, we often have the confidence to dream bigger with our skillset. There’s a catch: just because you could be very good at something, even at the mastery level, there is a huge difference between the top 10% and the top 1% that actually can make it in an industry. Life doesn’t give you too many chances and every step you take will have lasting consequences. For instance, if you bet your life on your sports career and you get hurt, that setback could hurt, if not end, your career. Therefore, the talent who does survive in those fields, tend to be paid above and beyond for their skill and sustainability, a reflection of the economic reality of a scarcity in the market of people who can perform at that level through the long-term. My mom saw my talent for what it was, a dangerous illusion that could rob me of my actual future that would instead need to be dependent on a long-term skill to survive. As we all know, in the entertainment industry, the life-span of most artists are relatively limited, so statistically, my odds of success were so low that my mom was terrified I’d actually sabotage my future pegged on my pipe dream. #3. Self-awareness on how much you’re willing to sacrifice will help you clarify your purpose. After college graduation, real life called. My parents made some business decisions that left me in charge of my family’s Chinese restaurant. That year, I progressed within a contest that asked me to go to China to compete on a national televised singing contest! However, by that point, I had a familial duty to help my parents survive. Our little restaurant paid the bills. If I left, there would be no one to pay our bills. How I hated my parents and extended family then! While everyone in my family was off pursuing their own interests, I was stuck doing my duty as a responsible and filial daughter, running a dinky restaurant that didn’t even pay me a real salary. I truly loathed my entire life, family, and the world for this gross injustice of watching my dreams die. However, I had to move on. I couldn’t live in hate or bitterness because it made me an angry and miserable person to be around. What I realized when I started reflecting on my life that year, was that it wasn’t my parents that I hated. It was myself and my own lack of confidence! Self-awareness proved to me that I didn’t have the guts to ditch my familial duties to pursue my dreams. That fault lies on me alone. If it were Madonna or Prince, they would have already left their parents. They probably wouldn’t have gone to college in the first place! They would have had the level of confidence required to run away from home for their dreams, throw their future away without any regrets. I didn’t have that same level of passion for my passion. #4. Move on to other passions. At age 22, I was too young to be struck down by life. I had too much optimism to let this early but great disappointment ruin my life. Even though I dreamed of Chinese popstar-dom as a singular objective, I had to find a way to move on as life after college progressed. After a period of bitterness and mourning, I started reading self-help books as a way to get on with my life. Once I fully accepted my own responsibility for my life, I analyzed my other passions. One of the reasons why I was so interested in singing, was for the most part, a desire for the reward that could be achieved once fame was acquired: wealth. That ultimately was the driver behind all my passions, the desire to live an extraordinary life, to possess the power that comes with financial success. Therefore, I shifted my focus into the passion to earn money, choosing to take a risk to become a headhunter, a career driven by commission, revenue generation, and sales mastery. I shifted my focus from singing to immersing myself into my sales career as a recruiter at 22. This decision changed my whole life. #5. Invest in a passion that you can create a true life off of with relatively low risk in accordance to your strengths. Since I didn’t want to work a boring 9–5 or work for 40 years before retiring, I wanted to fully maximize my sales job to take me out of poverty. I had no family money, still possessed student and car debt, and had no real skills outside of singing. The jobs I held were mostly blue collar like waitressing, bartending, landscaping, painting, helping out on simple white collar analyst jobs where I did administrative work. Through all those jobs, I slowly accumulated an advantage in one thing: communicating effectively with others. Since I had to manage difficult customers, handle a lot of stress relating to working grueling hours, and sometimes gross physical labor (cleaning out nasty oil traps, dealing with pests, etc.), I became very confident as a speaker and communicator and could tolerate tough working conditions. I knew how to sell an idea, persuade others, and interact with all types of people. I leveraged my communication skills into my recruitment job with the same dreams I possessed towards my first passion. I wanted to be world-class and famous as a recruiter. Since I worked at a global company, I reached immediate fame year one as a top rookie and my career continued to skyrocket. I went from being a broke and confused college graduate at 22 to earning over $215k yearly as a 25 year old top-biller. I became a real estate investor as a side hustle and parlayed all of my recruitment income into real estate and securities investments, eventually retiring at 28 from needing a job. #5. Continue refining your passions as your life, skillset, financial risk tolerance, and personal situation changes. If you asked me at 15 what my future would have been, I would have said something uneducated and irresponsible. In hindsight, I was much too naive and overconfident in my skills which, while good, were certainly limited. My work ethic and passion for my craft, while good, were not enough to truly be enough. Had I embarked on my journey to become a singer in China, I’m not sure where I’d be today. I’m not here to naysay against others’ dreams, but if you’re like me when it comes to singing, and feel that others got in the way of your own success, then you probably wouldn’t have become successful at it anyways! Even if you had others’ backing, the odds of success would have been the same. It’s not others’ that can change your reality; it’s ourselves who are driven by our own interests and persevere in our own endeavors. For many people who reach the top of their field, they did it DESPITE others’ naysaying. If you blame others for your lack of success, you will not only continue to fail, but also regress in your self-development. If I had truly possessed the same amount confidence to succeed I had going into recruitment, then I probably would have been able to realize my dream of becoming a singer. However, I didn’t and I still don’t. What changed was that, despite my mother’s protests on my career choice in sales, I knew I could succeed as a headhunter. For once, I found something I could not only be good at, but succeed at long-term. There are truly so many people out there better than me at singing. But in headhunting, I am in much more control and I’m now one of the top recruiters in my industry with a very distinct and sustainable competitive advantage. Best of all, since I focused on leveraging my passions in my career, I love what I do. Everyone’s passions will inevitably shift with the passage of time, aging, and also changes in family and financial demands. For instance, if I were to all of a sudden get married and have kids, my priorities and passions would change in an instant due to the demands of family life. There is no shame in pivoting and changing strategies. In Conclusion No matter what your passions and hobbies are, you’re in control of your life trajectory. You can increase your confidence and self-belief in the direction of passions that will actually create a sustainable life for yourself, and pay you back for your investment with a strong degree of certainty. The worst is to spend your whole life going after things that have a small chance of success and end up regretting the time you wasted and the economic opportunities you missed as a result of those poor choices. That’s why self-awareness of your capability, strengths, weaknesses, and competitive attributes can help pave the way through self-introspection on what path you should take and commit to. Ultimately, when you do determine your direction leveraging your talent and passion, you have to be responsible for that decision and see it through. As they say: the only way through is through. Once you make a commitment, you can’t keep shifting every other day. Focus, hard work, and perseverance are all required to achieve self-actualization.

MOST ABSTRACT/GROUNDLESS ADVICE IN THE WOLRD: “Follow your passion.” Hi. I'm 24 years old as well and I struggled with this very question for a long time. Only recently I've been able to overcome it. Here's how.. First of all, you need to understand that “follow your passion” is horrible advice that is basically making a ton self help gurus rich. It's the easiest thing to sell in the world as it feeds off our deepest fears and insecurity of living a boring and meaningless life. It's too abstract and way too generalized to help anyone. It's like saying “Be amazing”. Be amazing at what?? Second, there's an erroneous belief that to live a life of passion (or find a career your passionate about) you follow these steps: Find what you're passionate aboutGo after it as if your life depended on itWhat's wrong with that? Well considering most 18–26 year olds life experience includes sitting in a classroom reading outdated text books and getting wasted on the weekends, it's completely illogical to expect them to discover their passion. As if they could just have a dream about it and wake up knowing what they are destined to do the rest of their life So how do you discover your passion? Passion isn't something you just stumble upon. It's created. Think of the people you believe that have truly lived a life of passion. I'll use Steve Jobs for example because of his famous speech on following your passion. I truly believe Steve Jobs did live a life of passion and I'm sure most people would agree with me. But what most people fail to realize is that he didn't just wake up one day and decide he wanted to start the greatest computer company in the world. Hell, I don’t even believe he was passionate about computers. I believe he created his passion for them over time, but staring out he had no idea where he was headed. And more than a passion for computers and technology, he created a passion for how he could create amazing things and have an impact on people's lives. And he developed a passion around how much control he had over his professional life. But that didn't come overnight. It came through him working hard in a certain direction and taking the best opportunities that were presented to him Some people don't get as many opportunities as others, but that doesn't matter. You can still develop a life of passion no matter your circumstances. 3 INGREDIENTS TO A PASSIONATE AND MEANINGFUL CAREER CreativityImpactControlThinking of the Steve Jobs example, when you can have a career that allows you to create, have a positive impact on people (no matter how big or small), and have control, you'll begin to develop a passion for it—no matter what you do. It's not so much “what you're doing” as to “how you're doing it.” Especially right now when you're in your early to mid 20s. Right now the most important thing you can do is apply yourself to a career that you see will allow you to have these three aspects. Creativity. Impact. Control. You don't even have to worry about your “career”. Because the likelyhood of you staying with the same job your whole life is slim to none. Instead, focus on developing skills that will allow you to achieve a life with those three things. I suggest 4 particular skills that have extreme versatility that I believe can be applied to basically anything: MarketingSalesNetworkingLeadershipI chose these skills because they all directly apply to entrepreneurship. Usually, most people who want to live meaningful lives choose entrepreneurship because it's one of the only paths that allows you to have complete control over your life, create everyday, and your potential to have an impact on people's lives is limitless. But you don't have to be an entrepreneur. Many people live extremely meaningful lives that work as employees. But they usually all have the three ingredients, and it usually takes much longer to achieve. I hope this helps you demystify the “follow your passion” black hole. About a year ago I stopped trying to figure out what my passion was and started focusing on developing those skills listed above. Now I feel a passion and drive that I've never felt before. My life is slowly but surely becoming more and more clear of where I want to end up and I'm 100x more confident about where I'm headed. But in the dark confusing land of trying to discover my passion, everything seemed gray and the future was hazy. Get out of that land. P.S. If you want even more details on developing the skills that I've talked about, I wrote an article that dives deeper into this: Leaving Your Job For Your Passion Could Be The Biggest Mistake You Make. . .Unless you do it the right way. Cheers.

Forget about finding your passion. It's a bullshit platitude that doesn't mean anything. I'm INCREDIBLY passionate about the Grand Theft Auto games. Seriously, I put in hours and hours on those games when I was a kid (and I still do now). I could take or leave a lot of video games, but when it comes to GTA, I don't know anyone who loves that series more than I do. I could tell you the location of almost all of the gang tags in GTA:SA. I used to fly the Dodo around GTA3 for 2-3 hours at a time, just because I could. I still have a few songs by Love Fist on my iTunes. So I've found my passion. Great! The problem is, no one will pay me to sit on my arse all day playing GTA. I could write some guides about it, I could do YouTube gameplay videos, or I could get a job at Rockstar as a QA guy, but that would turn my passion into a job, and it wouldn't be interesting. So forget about finding your passion. It's not the magic bullet that you think it is, believe me. Not to mention that the idea you should do ONE THING and stick to that is nonsense. Look at Steve Jobs: he created amazing things at the intersection of art and technology. Elon Musk is at the intersection between physics and business. Here's what you need to do instead: develop useful skills. Pick something that you're somewhat interested in -- whether that's writing, programming, graphic design, accounting -- and get very, very good at it.  What skill should you pick to get good at? Well, what do you like doing? If the answer to that is "I don't know", then you need to get out there, and try lots and lots of different things. You can't just sit in a dark room, meditating and introspecting, completing personality questionnaires to figure out what colour your parachute is and what your MBTI is, and then emerge three days later having figured out exactly what they're supposed to do in life. You have to go out and interact with the real world, find something you like doing, and then focus -- REALLY FOCUS -- on that one thing, and become great at it. Because here's the secret. People don't get good at something because they're passionate about it. They become passionate once they become good at that thing. Passion follows performance. Go and pick up a copy of So Good They Can't Ignore You: Why Skills Trump Passion in the Quest for Work You Love by Cal Newport. Read it, cover to cover -- twice -- and then get to work. For more on careers, productivity, business, and decision-making, check out my blog at AndrewLynch.net.

Passion—it’s all about passion. Find your passion. Live passionately. Inspire the world with your passion. People go to Burning Man to find passion, to be around passion, to rekindle their passion. Same goes for TED and the now enormous SXSW and a thousand other events, retreats, and summits, all fueled by what they claim to be life’s most important force. Here’s what those same people haven’t told you: your passion may be the very thing holding you back from power or influence or accomplishment. Because just as often, we fail with—no, because of—passion. Early on in her ascendant political career, a visitor once spoke of Eleanor Roosevelt’s “passionate interest” in a piece of social legislation. The person had meant it as a compli­ment. But Eleanor’s response is illustrative. “Yes,” she did support the cause, she said. “But I hardly think the word ‘passionate’ applies to me.” As a genteel, accomplished, and patient woman born while the embers of the quiet Victorian virtues were still warm, Roo­sevelt was above passion. She had purpose. She had direction. She wasn’t driven by passion, but by reason. George W. Bush, Dick Cheney, and Donald Rumsfeld, on the other hand, were passionate about Iraq. Christopher McCandless was bursting with passion as he headed “into the wild.” So was Robert Falcon Scott as he set out to explore the arctic, bitten as he was with “the Pole mania” (as were many climbers of the tragic 1996 Everest climb, momentarily struck with what psychologists now call “goalodicy”). The inventor and investors of the Segway believed they had a world­ changing innovation on their hands and put everything into evangelizing it. That all of these talented, smart individuals were fervent believers in what they sought to do is without dispute. It’s also clear that they were also unprepared and incapable of grasping the objections and real concerns of everyone else around them. Passion in this sense is just ego. Pure and plain destructive ego. It’s self-absorption at the expense of reality.

You've got to go on an adventure, and explore through many different things. won't hurt to look in your past for clues either. When I was a little girl, my mum sent me for piano lessons. After just a few weeks, everyone started telling me that I was musically gifted and that that was one of the best things I could do in life, to pursue a career in playing the piano somehow. As that was one of the only skills I thought I had, I roled with it, never realising that it wasn't my true passion. Meanwhile, this same little girl found herself creating random stories out of nowhere, taking joy in using a video camera to make random videos and just singing in random places. It didn't really emerge until later, but a bit of acting was also involved. I started getting lots of creative ideas and started putting short stories onto paper. I started imagining vivid fictional worlds and characters and I also started wanting to make some sort of mini movie using my mum's phone's video camera. Creating was my thing, but I didn't know it at the time because I thought it was all just childish play. To me, this was fun, but piano was going to be my job, so I would focus on that . Then, when I turned 12, I started figuring out how to write songs with lyrics in them. They weren't that good, cringy even when I look back now but that ignited something in me. I wanted to sing, and keep singing, and harmonise... Though playing the piano brought me satisfaction, knowing I was good at something, it didn't bring me the joy singing did. So I joined my school's choir, and as the years passed, got exposed to many different types of music. I just wanted to sing them all. First, it was just my original songs but after a while, I also wanted to do my own renditions of songs that were already made, covers basically. I turned to YouTube as a means to try doing something I love. I had literally no experience with video editing, but I worked with what I had. As time passed and I began collaborating with more people on YouTube, I gained more knowledge and experiences on how to do it. As time passed, I found myself wanting to get more and more creative in order to make more interesting YouTube videos. I would experiment with scripts, story ideas, voice acting and stuff like that. Some of my friends introduced me to theatre musicals and I found myself enjoying them a great deal. I began trying to act out some scenes at home, while writing certain things out in script form to plan for future videos. I would audition for different projects and work on voice acting as there were a few people who had inspired me to try it even before I started my channel. I found myself enjoying the creative and learning experience a great deal and realising that, in a way it's a more professional version of the videos and stories I used to create as a child. Back then, I would also make videos, create my own characters and lines and, for the fun of it try to voice my own characters. I didn't know it was an actual passion of mine, but turns out it was! As for singing, I just found that it brought me great joy. Exploring different areas of it, I've come to realise which genres suit my voice. It took a bit of exploring, experimenting and even took some time, but soon I found the genre that best fits my voice, and it's none other than theatre musicals. Along with it, I started exploring new stuff and expanding from just merely voice acting to wanting to learn how to act in plays and musicals. As for writing, I had been doing it for years but the more I did it, the more I realised that putting my thoughts down or simply writing a fictional story gave me a sense of joy while I did it. But what about piano? What did I do with it? Well, today the piano is my primary instrument. I play it for fun and it helps me to write songs. However, I don't intend to pursue it professionally anymore. It's just not something I feel like I would like to do in life. Same goes with songwriting, I love it but it's mostly a way for me to get my feelings and emotions out. I don't intend to pursue that as a permanent profession either, at least in terms of releasing albums and stuff, but rather to do it as a hobby. I won't rule it out completely though. It's still early to say, Who knows, maybe I could combine it with my writing somehow and make some sort of script with original songs? You never know. Writing, singing and acting are my three main passions at least for now, but it took me awhile to find them because I once believed that there was a bridge between what I loved to do for fun and what I was learning to do for a professional career. That isn't always true. They don't necessarily have to be two separate things, one could just be an extension of the other. To find your dream, passion or purpose, look at what makes you happy, even if it's something as simple as making short videos, drawing or even getting creative with Legos. See what drives you forward, embrace what you love to do and go with it. It doesn't necessarily have to be something you are good at. It will take time, it might even take years to figure out what you truly like. But you will. Just keep trying, and never stop trying for you might discover new things about yourself as you go along, sometimes even things you didn't expect you would enjoy. One day, you will find your true passion! Good luck :)

This might not sound like other answers, but here goes: You CAN’T. You can’t FIND your passion; you CREATE your passion. Yes, there are some people who have a wonderful, transcendent moment that causes them to somehow forget themselves and immediately know what their passion is, but this isn’t you and it isn’t me. Stories like this are actually rare, and you can’t depend on them. What regular people like you and I have to do is simply find something that we want to do, however small, and begin to do it. With regular effort this can turn into a passion. I’ve gone through this myself with both comedy and sales and I can share with you how this is possible: Follow your desires, even if they’re “close to home” - When I started doing comedy (at the tender age of 14) I wasn’t looking to discover my passion, I was really trying to find a place for me away from kids who bullied me. But by going to improv classes (which was a club at my high school) and getting on stage I found I started to like improv. Soon I was trying to get up as much as possible, and was looking for even more and more opportunities, which lead to stand-up and a new career and passion.Find what you love about things you’re doing - After graduating from college I had no job. I’ve written about it before. I started doing independent sales as a necessity. At first it was the worst, and I was terrified about rejection. Soon, I started to appreciate the feeling of the thrill of the cold call, even if I hated and feared the rejection. Soon, I loved it more than the fear. Soon I loved it so much I tried to get it. Soon the fear didn’t matter at all and I began succeeding at sales. A passion was created.Set your goals, work to make them happen - That’s it. Once you feel that you have some control then push your edge. The working to get better will engender a passion of the material in you.It isn’t about discovering your passion, it’s about creating your passion. Your passion is created as you work yourself into the material of your life, lose yourself in it. Stay in touch with my latest comedy, articles, videos, and more on my email list. Sign up and get a FREE copy of The Lessons, a best-of my Quora answers.

The problem is that we've lost any real sense of what 'passion' means. It's not what gives you bliss or makes you happy 24/7, but what you're willing to suffer for -- what you genuinely believe to be worth the sacrifice. The next time you feel energized and strong and like the best version of yourself -- the you that you wish you could be all the time -- pay attention to what you're doing *in that moment*. Write it down. Do this for as long as it takes until you see a pattern emerging. It won't necessarily be the activities themselves -- but they will have something in common. Look into them and behind them until you find what dramatists call a throughline: the essence of what you're good at and what drives you. I spent most of my lifetime thinking that my passion is for writing, and for fiction in particular. But when I stepped back a bit and considered the other activities that light me up and make me feel a sense of wholeness (including my love of social media!), I realized that my passion is for emotional resonance, be it with a friend or spouse or audience or even the culture in general. I like moving into that sweetspot where something in my inner life overlaps with another consciousness, including a kind of group consciousness. That might sound like I should be lighting sticks of incense and showing off my dreamcatcher collection, but it is the *best* feeling. Writing is my main expression of that, but when I find ways to bring it into other areas of my life, I am a happy (happier) woman. We confuse the activity with the value behind the activity. It's the value that compels us -- and which we can transfer to paid-income work in a way that changes lives (and the industry itself). What Steve Jobs was passionate about was not computers per se, any more than it was calligraphy or Japanese gardening. It was simplicity*. He made it his obsession and his art. He introduced it to an industry that, as far as it was concerned, was doing just fine without it. Simplicity drove the Apple identity: the strategy, the products and marketing and branding, the presentations. Simplicity enabled a computer company to connect with mass culture on a deep, emotional level, when Jobs himself was not exactly Oprah (even if he also made people teary-eyed). Jobs brought it home just as fiercely: the complications of a couch, for example. His living room didn't require one. Passion matters -- given that you're likely to spend more time being deeply, truly involved with work that energizes you instead of depletes you -- or makes you want to stab your eyes out with your boss's mont blanc pen. When you can put in real, focused, quality time, you're a lot more efficient and can maybe also have a life. Imagine that. :) * Joe Pulizzi makes this point in his excellent upcoming book Content Inc. Highly recommended.

I would suggest that your question is flawed. It insinuates that everyone has one true passion. Some do. Famous people tend to be in this category, so the idea that everybody has one true passion gets overpopularized. Some people have more than one passion. And some people have nothing they are truly passionate about. But that doesn’t mean that everyone can’t find happiness in their career, which is I think the real question you are asking. Sit down and make a few lists. What are you naturally talented at. This can be things you are good at, or things you are *not* good at, but think you will be if you put in a year or three of practice.What do you enjoy. This can be things that truly rev your engine. But, in lieu of that, think about doing something for 8–10 hours consistently for 10 years. If that thought doesn’t make you depressed, you can put it on the list.What careers are profitable right now. These can be the obvious (doctor, lawyer, engineer), but also can be specific to the current or local economy. If you like languages, you might try picking up Arabic. If you live in the Gulf Coast, you might think about (re-)construction work. Don’t put things that are only lucrative for the top fraction (mobile app development, pro sports, grammy award winning pop star). You can put those things on other lists.What work is useful to your community. The greatest flaw with the trope about finding your passion is that it’s essentially narcissistic. We are social animals. Most of us measure our value in large part in whether other people find us valuable. Also, in a practical way, businesses need to be client-focused. And you are more likely to win at interviews if you are used to thinking about what value you bring to the person hiring you.The second list there is closest to “your passion”. But, the point of this exercise is to give a nod to that, but try to break away from it a bit. Look at all four lists and see what comes up most often. If something is on all four, it’s a slam dunk. But, it doesn’t have to be on all four. You can get better at something by raw practice. Don’t let not being good stop you from pursuing something you like, is profitable, and is useful. This is the path of the inspiring story: the Special Olympian, the ADHD Mathematician, the non-native English speaker who became a top lawyer.If you are good at something, make good money at it, and it’s useful to people, you don’t need to love the work to get fulfillment in your career. Pick up a hobby you love. This is the path of many doctors, lawyers and engineers.If you really enjoy something, are good at it, and your customers enjoy it, you can put up with the not making a lot of dough. This is the path of the artist, teacher, and most jobs in the non-profit sector.If you really enjoy something, you’re good at it, and its lucrative, then you can usually find the community that finds it useful. This is the path of many academics and engineers who work in esoteric fields.

If you need to “find” your passion it’s quite likely you simply don’t have one. Highly creative people are the ones who really need a passion in order to feel alive, and they usually know this as a fact since when they’re kids. They identify quite early in life what drives them, and you can’t really separate them from it. Be it making music, painting, building companies, doing research… If you don’t have such a burning drive to do something specific, it means that you’ve reached adulthood being exposed to a lot of things and never identified anything that triggered it. Unlikely. At this point, you should do some introspection and find out why you think you should even have it. Are you just following a (very American) cultural stereotype, something someone else told you that you’re supposed to have, based on nothing but motivational speaking? Most people seem to find a feeling of meaning and happiness in the sense of belonging to a community, in having children, and in helping other people (which is the reason why, as PayScale surveys show every year, the jobs in the healthcare sector are virtually the only ones where >80% workers state they think their job is meaningful to the world).Try volunteering and working for something community-based, and see if your feeling of lacking something (that you think is “a passion”) decreases or not. Also, I recommend reading the book So Good They Can’t Ignore You. It makes the case, supporting it with logic and evidence, that what most people call “passion” is actually just something they’ve become masters at. Mastery makes you love what you do, because it makes you feel competent, needed, and in control.But maybe saying “work seriously on something complex for 10 years and you’ll have a passion” is a less marketable concept to the masses than suggesting them they’ll find one under a rock while they’re hiking…

If someone had asked me four years ago on pursuing my passion, I would have said blogging/YouTubing etc and if that question had been asked six years ago I would have gone blank not knowing what a passion is. When I was a little girl, I would day-dream and sketch abstract things. Then I discovered books and immersed myself into the world of stories. Somewhere along the way I lost my love for reading and got distracted in other teenage stuff. At 19 I discovered YouTube, watched and learned great things. It’s through YouTube I realised how each one of us longs for an outlet of their creative expression. I created my website and started blogging. 2016; a booming time for fashion bloggers/YouTubers. I would write blogs on my style and post perfectly curated fashion photos. Being an economics graduate, I tried merging finance with fashion aka minimalism Although people loved reading my blogs, I failed miserably in that field. I also didn’t have a regular job for me to afford new clothes and makeup. I couldn’t do what was needed to become successful in that area; consistency that is. I was not consistent and not doing enough for me to be able to start earning from a blog. Then I switched towards YouTube and it was not at all fun. Filming and editing a single video would take me minimum of 6 to 7 days. I have to admit that receiving positive feedback and the impact it started making on my confidence levels pushed me to keep going. Bottom line is that my YouTube channel has also stalled and I have probably failed to make a mark on that outlet as well. Both of these experiences have taught me great lessons about pursuing our passions. Sometimes we confuse passion with the need to get validation to overcompensate for our insecurities. However, there are great benefits with trying different things even just for the sake of getting a kick of validation or money. With trying different things we not only realise about our strengths and weaknesses but also about our “WHY” Knowing our “Why” is utterly important in knowing of our passions. Our “Why” is what pushes us after failing a hundredth time. If your “Why” is not powerful enough, you will give up the pursuit of it. Over the years I have given up many things but the only thing I refuse to give up ever is to write and inspire. I believe I might have found my purpose :) My Take: Do anything and everything, your passion will arrive knocking on your door

You don't have one. Passion is developed, not found. At age 14, I decided to be an industrial designer. 7 years later, 2 years into my industrial design program, I switched to biophysics. 2 years after that, I was an intern in hospital administration. I had passion for industrial design. I thought it was really cool, and I thought I could spend forever doing it. I still like design, but I don't have passion for it anymore. I don't want to work in that field. If I was relying on passion, I would probably be stuck in a low-paying internship or a job I didn't enjoy very much. And my passion would have been squashed. But my passion has grown in a different field. And I picked healthcare administration because of skills that were stronger - I'm better at math and analytical thinking than I am at design. I found the problems more interesting and rewarding. But I didn't pick healthcare because of passion, not at all. I think passion is emotional, and thus unreliable. Passion will come and go, but is more likely to be present when you're doing something you're skilled at and that you find interesting. I work as an analyst in healthcare - it's not a sexy job, but I'm really excited about it. I find my work interesting. At times, I feel passion for it. But it's nearly impossible to find a job or career that you will be passionate about 40 hours a week, 52 weeks a year. Passion is also not immediate. I developed my passion for healthcare (and it is transient, not permanent) over time, by volunteering, interning, reading, working, and researching the field. I didn't wake up one day in my undergrad and realize I had passion. It came with time. I could develop passion for anything. There are plenty of fields you could develop passion for, too. But more important is to develop skill and expertise. When you start to have success, you'll find you have more passion. I have the most passion for my job on the days that I'm kicking ass and delivering really useful information to administration or to physicians. I feel like what I'm doing is important, and I derive pride from that. But on a slow day, or on a day where I'm struggling, I have little to no passion for my work. If I was relying on passion, I'd be a leaf tossed about in the wind, with no roots or permanence anywhere. Chasing passion isn't a good way to live life, whether that's in jobs or in relationships. It comes and goes. Enjoy it when it shows up. You'll never know what you want without gaining experience and doing practice.

The problem with finding your passion is that multiple layers of institutions that have worked against you to actually find it. These include: your parents, often whom want you to become themselves, or achieve the goals that they themselves could not achieveyour schools, often whom want you to become a factory worker or corporate droneyour government, often whom wants you to become whatever gives them the most in tax-dollarsyour friends, often whom wants you to become follow whatever they dothe media, often whom want to you to travel the world and “find yourself” without any regard to money, opportunity cost, or family obligationsTo strip out all this, you need to go back to your primal needs. Humans are governed by three primary needs: self-esteemindependencelove / connectionWe each all crave a bit of each of these. And in fact we each struggle balancing these needs as we develop in our lives. But each of us tend towards differing points along the circle.  Each area represents a different way to gain acceptance within our society. For instance, all societies and cultures evolved to preserve their survival by building up a status quo and having everyone adhere to it. This is linked to self-esteem, since self-esteem is only gained when we break through guideposts set up by our society. Societies also need to ensure we have independent thinkers. People whom are seeking out new ways to do things, in case the environment changes rapidly which threatens our survival. Rebels that can push us to think outside the status quo. This is linked to truth. Societies also need people to stick together. People who can act as the glue to maintain solidarity. People whom can keep everyone working together healthily and happily. This is linked to connection. We can see this most clearly in families, which act as mini-communities in today’s modern world. Here are some tendencies that persist across cultures around the world (note: sibling studies are hopelessly controversial so I won’t dwell on absolutes - these are just rough tendencies): First-borns tend towards self-esteem (#1). They gain most satisfaction when they are gaining attention, money, fame, or status. They struggle to connect with others based on love or based on truth. They are adept at working within the boundaries set up within their environment. This means working up corporate hierarchies and become managers, grinding through medical school to be a doctor, etc, and then earning the degrees / certifications that give them prestige.Middle children tend towards truth (#2). These folks tend to very strong at people-skills, negotiating, and listening. Unlike first borns, they tend to be highly attuned to their environment. They question their environment rather than work within it, and thereby tend to be more truth-seeking. They are better at learning languages, studying cultures. They also tend towards more individualistic pursuits - academics, repairmen, artists, etc. Truth is what makes them happy.Youngest children tend towards connection (#3). These folks tend to be strong at understanding their own emotions and discerning others’. They gain satisfaction from making others feel better and establish emotional connections with others. They gain satisfaction by strengthen the linkages within their community. Passions linked to this range from acting to comedy to HR to psychology to nursing.There are multiple types of exceptions. Absent parents can create distortions. Sickness in the family can also distort things. And single children tend to have a mix of all of these. But even they tend to focus on one area for their passion. To understand your passion, you need to understand what’s your driver. Once you find your driver, you’re halfway there. Sources: Your younger sibling is funnier than you (at least that’s what they say) Birth Order in the Workplace A new economic study shows how your birth order can influence your career Here's Why Your Older Brother Is So Irritatingly Successful

The depth of this question is something that people spend far too little time uncovering and understanding. The majority of people in North America do the exact same thing every day for 30 plus years until they retire, and then by that time their health has deteriorated, their savings have dwindled, and they are too miserable to enjoy the life they thought they would. The reason for this is that they resigned themselves to a career that simply paid the bills but did not fulfill them mentally, physically or spiritually. In fact, it actually did the opposite and had an adverse effect on their physiology and well-being. I have seen people who absolutely love their job and find happiness in the smallest nuances it brings, but then I have seen the opposite where they dread Monday morning and just wait for the weekend. Which one are you? Regardless of what you may have been conditioned to think, each and every person has unique and special talents that this world needs and requires. What are your God-given talents…and are you using them in your career or day-to-day endeavors? No two people are alike and you have been carefully created to bring something extremely valuable to this material existence. If you keep an open mind and be aware of your surroundings, you will notice the diverse and unique skills of the human race. We have doctors, lawyers, caregivers, scientists, teachers, sales professionals, athletes, tradesman, entrepreneurs, specialists, and more. You have been specifically called to tap into your inherent abilities so you can fulfill your obligation to society. Consider these questions: What are you good at? What things do people come to you for guidance about? In what areas are you considered to be an expert? If you haven’t already discovered this and feel like you are drifting on open water then I suggest you pay close attention to the following two points. The first one is to ask your friends and the people around you to tell you what they feel you are good at. What do you do well? How would they define you? What skills do they see in you? The people who have known you for many years can see things that you cannot. These people will be honest and transparent about your talents. Also consider: What are you passionate about? What brings out the fire in you? When do you feel most alive? It is so evident when you see people talk about a subject they really enjoy speaking about. They light up and have this energy that is contagious and infectious. It elevates the atmosphere in the room. Some of the best ideas come from people that pursue their passion and take the time to hone it every day. Passion means wanting to learn more about that discipline or topic, and wanting to be a pioneer in that field and really become an expert. You should never stop educating yourself and you should prophesize about it wherever possible. Passion is not something that you can teach or learn in a class. It is inherent in you and has a deep foundation within your inner being.

One important question before I answer this question- Why should you find a passion when you don't have any? Having passion is not the best way of life. Passion gives you high expectations which are generally followed by a life long headache of frustration. It gives you dedication and madness towards one particular goal in life, and then in the pursuit, you ignore every other aspect of life.  After spending years towards your passion and ignoring everything else, there are three options- Either you will fail, succeed, or lie somewhere in between. Only success can justify your efforts and make you happy. But the probability of success is not too high. Thus most probably you will end up regretting the beautiful life you left behind. And if you have a passion but ignore it, you will still end up regretting all life. Passion is a two sided coin, where both the sides may result in loss for a person. The sleepless nights, being busy in crucial times of loved ones, missing the beautiful moments of fun and love with spouse, ignoring the love of kids and parents etc are all non refundable capital expenses.  Let's talk about success now! Even if you manage to unlock the doors of success, you will still enter into a beautiful yet empty room, where you most probably won't know what to do next? The feeling of achievement may be subsided very soon, supressed by the years of efforts and sacrifices. Ultimately you will realise that- “The destination is a point while the journey is life”  I am not against following your passion. If you are passionate about something, your life revolves around your passion, you shouldn't avoid it. But why search for it going out of the way? A simple undisturbed life is a gift of God, it is the way we are born to live, try and seek happiness in it. There is so much to life- Spend time with parents, siblings, cousins.Eat good food, sleep well, keep yourself fit.Enjoy the different weathers, festivals.See closely your children growing up, play with them, teach them.Enjoy an intimate relationship with your life partner, travel together, spend more time together.Save and buy gifts for your loved ones, surprise them, make them happy.Enjoy small achievements like salary increment, bagging a big order in business, first car, own house etc.Spend hours with friends chatting, joking and laughing.Relax yourself on a holiday, lie down on bed, watch TV, sip tea.Help people and animals, feel important and good about yourself.Set small achievable goals, work for them and enjoy the success. Finally answering the question, “How can I find my passion?”- Passion is not a goal or a product which you can search outside. It is an instinct, an internal drive, craziness towards something which is automatically generated at the back of your mind.Sometimes we are born with a talent or passion for something and sometimes we may realise our passion during the course of life.If you forcefully create a passion for something by seeing others succeeding in a field, your chances of working with dedication in long run fall along along with the chances of success.Though you can always create manageable goals, followed by hard work and minimum expectations.  This is my perspective towards this topic. Though it may sound a bit pessimistic but from my experience it appears to be a more practical way of life. Rest is your choice. Best of luck :) Thanks for A2A Prachita Bakliwal.

Ways To Find Your Life's Passion And A Career For Success By Love Droid ,Love Droid \U0001f60d  I grew up in Siberia where my dad was a political journalist. He taught me to question everything around me and to take nothing at face value. My mom was a nonconformist by nature, best expressed by the fact that, if she wanted something, there was no stopping her. It didn’t matter how the system worked or what people around her thought or did. She set her own rules. These two traits — questioning everything and being unafraid to go after what I want — defined who I am. By the time I moved to the US when I was 16, I knew that I wasn’t going to accept an average 9-to-5 as a career. My time had to be spend on something big, all encompassing and long term and, most importantly, something I would be really passionate about and could really get behind. I set out for Cornell University determined to find my passion. In college I moved quickly from one subject to the next looking for my passion, taking classes ranging from psychology to computer science, neuroscience, fine art and finally film. Although learning was always fun, I just couldn’t get sufficiently motivated by academic goals set in that artificial environment. This led me to leave Cornell only two classes short of graduation. I later found that solving real problems and building something around opportunities I discover is what I’m truly motivated by. Today, I’m fortunate to say that I have, in fact, found my passion and am doing what I love — building a startup around a set of problems that I believe need solving. In the meantime, I continue to observe people of all ages around me struggle with finding a job they love. In looking at my own path of getting to do what I love, I’m observing four main lessons. 1. When You Know It’s Not Working, Quit Fast Many people hate their jobs and know that they want to do something different, but stay in their hated jobs for a long time nonetheless. Their main reason for not leaving is that they haven’t actually figured out what it is that they want to do. This thinking is flawed because you won’t learn or discover your ideal career or job by sitting around and thinking about it. If the current situation isn’t working, you need to find something else. What happens when you leave even without knowing what you will do next is that, suddenly, figuring out your next steps becomes urgent. That urgency may be a bit uncomfortable, but it can also be incredibly powerful because it frees you up to invest all of your energy into finding the next thing. Finding the next thing goes from optional to required. I personally have left several jobs prematurely, not only not knowing what I will do next, but also exited with no savings to see me through the period of not working. The very last job I left was a startup where I found myself wanting to do a lot more and the company not really needing what I wanted to give. I was at this startup for about nine months and found myself in a position where it felt that I was simply exchanging my time for money. Frustrated, I tried giving feedback to the management and eventually gave notice without much planning. To my surprise, I was offered two weeks of severance, which were much-much needed since I had no savings to hold me over. In all cases, I found that leaving was the right thing as it forced me to keep searching for my next step with urgency and to eventually found the company I now love building. 2. Follow Your Curiosity Even though you may not have a clear vision for your career, you are probably curious about things which may or may not be obvious to you. It’s important to follow your curiosity and uncover your less obvious interests. The reason it’s important is that those interests tap into your unique motivations that separate you from others. Pursuing them sets you on the path of unlocking who you are and your creativity. Frequently, these will be things that do not appear pragmatic and sometimes may seem downright frivolous. A classic example is Steve Jobs’ curiosity for typefaces which led him to attend a seemingly useless class on typography and to develop his design sensibility. Later, this sensibility became an essential part of Apple computers and Apple’s core differentiator in the marketplace. A good way to tune into these interests is to ask yourself what you would do if you had a billion dollars. By my third year of college, I looked through Cornell’s entire giant catalog and couldn’t get excited about any of the classes in it. I had sampled many of the disciplines and felt that I was at a dead end. Frustrated, I finally pushed myself to think about what I would be interested in doing if money were of no concern. To my surprise, that led me to fantasize about drawing and painting. I also realized that I perceived both of these disciplines as forbidden. I believed that my parents would disapprove and that it would be a highly impractical area of study to pursue. Yet, I also realized that I was genuinely excited about fine art and took the plunge which became an important stepping stone in my path. 3. Don’t Make Money Your Primary Consideration My first startup was in New York City. At the time, I had college loans and limited income from freelancing as a video editor, and I lived with my dad and stepmom in New Jersey. One of the partners of my startup invested a small amount of money into the company — just enough to do the basics, such as open a small office in Manhattan. Commuting from my parents’ house was a pain, so I brought in a sleeping bag to our office, got a gym membership and would often stay at the office overnight. It was not ideal, but alternatives, such as spending my time on making money instead of working on the startup, didn’t make sense to me. If you’re looking to spend your life doing something you love, the best way to start is to treat financial concerns as secondary. If the practicality of what you do and how much money you earn are your primary criteria you will instantly limit your options to what’s predictable and getting to do what you love will be tough. On the other hand, if you allow yourself to pursue your curiosity, you will find yourself in the position of power and, eventually, in the position to earn money on your terms. Connecting to your unique interests and motivations and coming into your own authentic self, gives you power in your chosen discipline that others can’t claim. The reason for this is the unique fit of these interests to who you are. For others, what you choose to do may seem like a huge chore, but for you it won’t even feel like work. When your work fits who you are so well, you stand out as being uniquely capable and uniquely powerful. And the better you get at expressing yourself through your work, the higher your earning potential will be in that capacity. 4. Don’t Set An Artificial Ceiling For Yourself Your professional ceiling is set by you. At some point in the past, I hired a designer and didn’t give her an official title. When I started receiving email from her I noticed that she added the word “Junior” to her designer title. I found that quite surprising since that title had never been discussed. For her, this was a way to limit the amount of responsibility she took on, as well as the expectations others would have of her. Since then, I’ve seen many examples of how people define their own ceilings and avoid responsibility and growth. If you do so by choice, I respect it. On the other hand, if you want more growth, then don’t hide behind the belief that someone else needs to empower you to do what you want to do.
