To find your passion, you should first take a look at your own life and  see if you're already doing something that you love -- but just not  doing it very often. Figuring out what you really love to do and  channeling it in a productive way that turns it into a passion can help  you explore your heart's desires. Here are some of the things you should  ask yourself when you brainstorm what you love to do: What are my goals?What do I do most of the time?What do I keep on trying to do?If I could do one thing for the rest of my life, what would it be?What do I love to do?What would I do, even if I didn't get paid to do it?What makes me feel like nothing else exists?What activity makes me feel completely in my element?Think about what you've always dreamed of doing. This  is different from making a list of all of the things that make you  happy. Here, you'll have to write down all of those things you've always  dreamed about, but haven't done because you don't have the time, the  money, or because they're impractical or even slightly scary. Here are  the questions you should ask yourself as you brainstorm what you've  always dreamed of doing: What is the one thing I have always dreamed about, but never got to do?What did I want to do when I was a child?Do I have an impractical dream that I once abandoned?Is there something I've been afraid to try because it takes me out of my comfort zone?Is there something I've been wanting to do but haven't done because of financial fears?Is there something I've always wanted to do but haven't tried because I've been afraid I'd fail or just not be very good at it?Is there something that someone I know does that thrills me?Create a game plan. Once you've written down the  answers to your questions, you may have a better idea of the type of  things that already interest you or the things that you've always wanted  to try. Now that you have a bit more information, you can create a plan  for finding your passion. Here are some things you can decide to do:Make a goal of trying at least five things on your list. Plug them  into your calendar. Make a plan for actually doing these things as soon  as you can, even if that means within a year, if the activities are more  complicated, like traveling to a foreign country.Make a goal of trying a few completely new things that take you out  of your comfort zone. They don't have to be on your list -- you can just  try a few more things that pique your interest, even if you haven't  necessarily always dreamed of doing them or tried them before.Prioritize your potential passions. Decide which things you'd like  to try first. You can try the ones that sound most intriguing first, or  you can try the most practical ones first.

1) Inventory your talents What are you good at or have a natural aptitude for? Forget about what you’re good at but don’t really like doing much. I’m talking about the things you have a knack for that delight or happily occupy you. Are there things you like to do that you don’t think you’re that good at, that other people have complimented you on? Perhaps you even dismissed or rejected their enthusiasm. After much digging and questioning (I am a passion hound) I recently discovered that one of my coaching clients loves taking pictures. She rarely picks up her camera, as she didn’t think she was any good. I asked her to email me some favorite shots and they were fantastic. She was skeptical at first, but when I convinced her that I knew what I was talking about (I have earned income from my own photography) she could hardly contain her excitement. She finally had “permission” to fully embrace this pastime that she loves so much. Yet when I had asked about her passions in our first session, she had come up empty. Identifying things you love that you’re good at is a great way to unearth potential passions. Don't be concerned if what you love isn't practical or common (I get very excited about the uncommon). Please note though that you don’t have to be good at something for it to quality as a passion. You don't have to ever earn a penny of income from it either. Talent can simply be a clue. When it comes to your passions, the only thing that matters is that you enjoy them. 2) Pay attention to who makes you annoyed or jealous Are there people doing things that are “frivolous” who annoy you? Take a closer look at that annoyance. Is the truth behind your annoyance that you really wish you could live so freely, that you didn’t have so many serious responsibilities and could be as “immature” as they are? After a lifetime of being an overachieving do-what-everyone-expects-of-me student, when I embarked on my Mexican adventure at 33 I wanted to give myself a break and find time to pursue my freshly discovered passions for writing and dancing. Most people thought I was nuts, but my father got the angriest. He told me I was wasting my life and should let him help me set up my own clinic instead. He pounded the kitchen table with his fist, shouting “Life isn’t supposed to be fun! When are you going to grow up like the rest of us?” Thankfully I ignored him, as I did everyone else who tried to discourage me. A few years later, when it was clear that living, writing and dancing in Mexico was one of the best decisions (and career moves) I ever made, my dad sold his business. And moved to Hawaii. To write his first novel. I’m convinced he was largely so upset because he wanted to do what I was doing. At the time, I’m quite sure he didn’t know that. But eventually he figured it out! 3) Think of what you loved to do as a child This is probably the simplest way to unearth what pursuits hold the potential to light up your days. Before the grown-ups get to us with their ideas, most of us know exactly who we are and what would make us happiest. Were you obsessed with horses? Maybe you should head to a dude ranch for your next vacation. Loved finger painting or drawing? Sign up for an art class. Sang at the top of your lungs until people begged you to stop? Think about joining a local choir (or starting your own garage band!) 4) Notice when you lose track of time, or what you hate to stop doing When I work at the clinic seeing a long line-up of sore throats and knees, I watch the clock all day until I’m finally done. Yet when I have a patient in front of me who is depressed or anxious or newly diagnosed with a condition that would benefit from lifestyle change, I often lose my usual urgency and spend a big chunk of time with them. Not surprisingly, my true passion is life and health coaching, where I have the luxury of time with clients and love spending great swaths of time teaching and encouraging. I dance flamenco until my legs or body force me to stop. I also love working on my "Health and Happiness Expert" business so much that I have to force myself to stop writing and reading to sleep and eat and play. It’s reverse clock-watching – I get annoyed as time goes by! What a different world. What would you love to spend hours doing, that you never get enough time to do? That’s a passion, and you probably need to do it more than you are. 5) See your passion hunt as a fun, joyful adventure In my coaching and speaking work I see people putting pressure on themselves to find their passion. I do believe it’s critically important to discover and engage in things that light you up, but it’s just as important to cultivate an un-serious child-like attitude of play, wonder and adventure. When you deliberately open yourself to noticing things you might enjoy doing, don’t be afraid of getting it wrong. It’s all an adventure, you’re learning and growing as you go. Happiness research shows that trying new things increases dopamine levels in the brain, contributing to sustained levels of contentment. So try away! Notice what you love. Notice what makes you feel like a kid. Notice what you long to have more time for. Make time for these things, whatever you can manage, and watch your life start to change. It’s really magical

I think everyone are passionate about something or the other, but they just simply don’t know it. I suspect you too fall in the same category. So, one needs to know what a passion looks like, feels like! Passion is something that “Pulls” you towards it. That is, something that you cannot live without and how much ever you try to get away from it, it simply brings you back and you end up doing more and more of it. For instance, some people are passionate about Music. They listen to songs, they talk about songs, they recommend and share music with a lot of people and they think that those who don’t listen to music are really a strange lot. They find time to listen, talk, discuss, recommend and share music. It has to be a part of their daily routine. Let me also say that Passion is NOT something that you do during your free time. Passion is something that you compels you TO FIND TIME TO DO IT. To figure out what you are passionate about, just watch out what you would like to do, what do you like to talk about all the time, what pulls you into it and immerses you into it, what is that which you keep doing and when you don’t do it, you find that something is missing. You already know the answer, because you already are passionate about something! So just get it. Well, if you tried and didn’t get it, then relax! Maybe your passion has not yet shown itself out. Give it time. It will come to you!!

Everyone tells you to “Do what you love!” It’s great advice, but what if you don’t yet know what kind of work will be most fulfilling? Search high and low Pick absolutely anything that interests you and type that word or phrase into the “Advanced Search” box on LinkedIn. For instance, let’s say you love basketball. Just type “basketball” and your results will include the profiles of anyone on LinkedIn who mentions the sport in his or her profile. Review these profiles to discover the professional and educational experience, skills and qualities needed to land various positions related tobasketball and see if any organizations, job functions or groups in these peoples’ profiles catch your eye as potential options for you. Don’t love what you find? Try searching on a different term! Be a joiner You can join groups on LinkedIn related to any career interest that even vaguely appeals to you. Go ahead and explore! If you like cooking, join a group for professional chefs. If you’ve fantasized about starting your own business, join a group for entrepreneurs. Then, if you find yourself really engaged in the content, start contributing to discussions and connecting with other members. Your interest may be an indication that this is a career path you should pursue. On the other hand, if you lose interest after receiving a few updates from a group, then that profession might not be the best choice for you. Connect with passionate people Look around your life for other people who share your passions -- or any passion. Just as you should connect on LinkedIn with people who share your alma mater or a past internship employer, you should also connect with people who share your personal interests or hobbies. Look for people who inspire you in groups and send them a connection request asking for a few words of wisdom. Most passionate people are happy to share their excitement about what they do. Don’t be afraid to fail It’s unlikely that you’ll find your passion just by sitting at your computer. You have to go out in the world and try new things. Do more volunteering, take on part-time work, sign up for a class in something you’ve never studied. Use LinkedIn to discover your passion and find opportunities, and then get out there and take action! Your path is out there, just waiting to be discovered.

“You have to be burning with an idea, or a problem, or a wrong that you want to right. If you’re not passionate enough from the start, you’ll never stick it out.” Steve Jobs The passion you are looking for with every ounce of your being is not found somewhere else in the world. You might look for it from an external source (self-help books, inspirational audios, mentors, billionaires, leaders, friends, etc.) They can tell you their own experiences and how they have found their passion (if they have). They can share with you the path they have taken to find this thing called passion. But none of them can tell you what your passion is. None of them can tell you what you are passionate about. Only you can do that. The only one who can find out what your passion is you.   There is an ancient story where a young man looked for Socrates looking for wisdom. Here’s the account of the story: “A young man asked Socrates, “Will you please teach me all I need to know and all I need to learn to be a success?” Socrates nodded and said, “Absolutely.” Then he started walking toward the ocean with the young man following in step. Once on the sand, Socrates continued to walk straight into the water. The young man followed. When both were chest deep in the ocean, Socrates placed his hands on the young man’s head and quickly forced it under the water. After about ten seconds, the young man fought his way to the surface and began to gasp for air. Socrates released the boy’s head, turned and walked away. The young man did this three times. He went to Socrates. He asked the same question. Socrates did the same thing and walked away. At the end of the third attempt, the young man ran after Socrates. When he was a few feet from Socrates he shouted, “Socrates, why is it every time I come to you and ask for your help to gain the wisdom and the knowledge on how to be a great success, all you do is take me out in the water and dunk my head?” Socrates turned around, faced the young man, and said, “Son, I have tried three times now to teach you the secret of being a great success. The secret is simple: When you want to succeed as much as you want to breathe, you will be a great success.” I totally agree. Even though Socrates was talking about success, I can say that the message works in finding your passion as well. You know that you have found your passion when you cannot live without it. You know that you have found your passion when you need it like the very air you crave when you are underwater. If you don’t feel the craving for “this thing” like you crave air for your existence, then you have not yet found your passion.  How do you find your passion? Answer these questions for yourself: ·Is there anything that you do consistently even when you do not have enough time? · Do you find ways in your spare time to accommodate “this thing”? ·Do you lose track of time when you are immersed in “this thing”? ·Does your heart speeds up when you talk about “this thing” to your friend or a member of your family? ·Are you internally motivated to do “this thing”? ·Will you do “this thing” even if you are not paid a penny? ·Do you enjoy “this thing”? Do you see “this thing” as play rather than work? ·Do you get up quickly after a setback? ·Does “this thing” feeds your soul – rather than drain your energy? ·Do you want to learn everything about “this thing”? · Do you want to be the best at “this thing”? · Are you no longer interested in distractions like Social Media because you’re always immersed in “your thing”? · Do you take more risks for “this thing”? “This thing” implies your passion. If you’ve answered the above questions that means you know with certainty what you are passionate about it. All you have to do next is to make sacrifices so that your passion precedes other activities, so that it becomes a priority, so that you can give it your whole. Jim Rohn said it best: “When you know what you want, and want it bad enough, you will find a way to get it.” If you were not able to answer the above questions, then it is time to dig deeper within yourself. Losing track of time If you pay close attention to what you do throughout the day, you will find out which activity has gotten your complete attention. Have you lost track of time when you were preparing a dish? Have you lost track of time when you were leading your team? Have you lost track of time when you were creating some sort of art? Or while writing? Did you lose time when you were negotiating a deal with your clients? Did you lose time when you were writing codes in front of your laptop? Pay close attention. It’s crazy how we lose sight of “the thing” we love the most by not paying enough attention. If you can’t find something that is making you lose track of time in your recent days, go back. To your teenage years. To your childhood day. Excitement is the key “Passion is energy. Feel the power that comes from focusing on what excites you.” Oprah Winfrey Find that thing that excites you. Like a fire that burns from within, when you find this thing, everybody around you can tell that you and this thing has a long-term relationship. And that no one and no force on earth is going to separate the two of you (one being you and the other being your passion) even if they try all their lives. You have a relationship with your passion because it is based on the love you have for each other. This love cannot be explained on paper simply. You either have it or you don’t. I give you a simple example: When I sit down in front of my laptop to write, the feeling I always have is euphoric. I cannot explain it to you. I love it. I feel like if I don’t yet, I would suffocate. That is how I know writing is my passion. Mia Hamm said: “If you don’t love what you do, you won’t do it with much conviction or passion.” It is the love that creates an enduring excitement. Internal motivation You know you’ve found your passion when you are internally motivated. When something inside of you is the force that is making you do something or chase something relentlessly, you know that you’ve got it. You will do “this thing” even if you are not paid a penny Doing something because you are going to be paid is completely different from doing something because you cannot think of not doing “this thing”. You have to ask yourself: Why are you doing this thing or that thing? Is it because you are going to be paid or is it because you want and need to do this thing – even if you are not paid? If it is the former - then that is not really your passion. Of course, it is great to be paid, but that should not be your primary goal if you are looking for your passion. You become energetic When you find your passion. You can only feel energetic about something when you love it with all your heart, when that thing is the major part of your life and you are extremely happy about it. You do not easily get tired. Because you are doing something that you love. Because you can’t wait to get back to it. Because the energy is coming from within. When something feeds your soul –your energy can never be drained from you. The supply is coming from an endless source. And that is you. Your passion must be at the top in your priority list You cannot really be passionate about something if that thing is found at the middle or the bottom of your lists. You ought to put this thing on the top. If you cannot see this thing as the most important thing that you must pursue, then you do not love it enough. If you do not crave this thing with every fiber of your being, if you do not love it more than the other things you’re chasing, then that means “that thing” is not really your passion. Here’s what the late Steve Jobs said on the subject: “You’ve got to find what you love. And that is as true for your work as it is for your lovers. Your work is going to fill a large part of your life, and the only way to be truly satisfied is to do what you believe is great work. And the only way to do great work is to love what you do. If you haven’t found it yet, keep looking. Don’t settle. As with all matters of the heart, you’ll know when you find it. And, like any great relationship, it just gets better as the years roll on. So keep looking until you find it. Don’t settle.” Now, are you ready to find your passion? I have found out what mine is, what is yours?  (Image Credit - Google Images) Enjoyed this? Join my readers for similar inspirational contents - Banchi Inspirations.

The word passion is a misnomer. The meaning of the word itself is probably half the reason you haven’t found yours yet. You’re expecting it to be something huge you’ll have incredible feelings for, bigger than anything you’ve ever dreamed of because you know, you’re gonna be so passionate about it! In reality, strong emotions are short-lived, like fireworks. Fireworks erupt in a blaze of glory but quickly fizzle, leaving just wisps of smoke and a memory of what was once spectacular. — Angela Duckworth That’s why most people who haven’t found their passion yet are having such a hard time finding one because they’re not that obvious. It turns out passions don’t just fall out of the sky already formed like the stork just delivered ‘em, you have to develop them yourself, following the few simple steps outlined below. Your passion is hiding right under your nose Getting started with finding your passion is as easy as picking up one of the many things you’re already interested in, meaning you like the thing and think you’ll enjoy doing it and getting busy. I mean, you do like something, right? At least you think you do. You’re gonna spend a lot of time wrestling with that one thing to find out how much you really like it. The key is to stop overthinking and just get started. A child does not walk onto a playground and say to herself, “How do I find fun?” She just goes and has fun. — Mark Manson Picking your thing is easy. Doing it for any length of time is less so. Your first hurdle is sometimes your last “Enthusiasm is common. Endurance is rare.” — Angela Duckworth So, you chose a thing, and then you did the thing. Congratulations! Everything has been going great so far, but unfortunately, there will come a time when you hit a setback, slump, or get knocked down. This is the point where you will decide how much you really like your thing. It’s okay if you wanna give up your thing and choose another one. There’s a chance you might not find your thing on your first or even second try, and that’s fine. You’re making progress either way, and I’m proud of you, kiddo! But on the other hand, maybe you loveyour thing, and you just can’t wait to wake up from the total knockout you were just dealt to keep at it. Good for you. You’ve got some of that true grit, champ. Some of that good old fashioned pluckiness. The ability to come back the next day and do it all again is really going to help you develop your passion. Stuck in the middle with you Choosing to stick with your thing despite a setback is admirable, and it’s what I like to see, but it’s no time to rest on your laurels. Things aren’t going to get easier for a while, in fact, this is the point where you might feel like you’re treading water. If you’re going to get anywhere with this thing of yours, you’re gonna have to get better at it. That’s where deliberate practice comes into play. Don’t worry, I won’t bore you with the details now, you should be looking into it on your own time anyway, I’m just outlining your overall path! What, do you want me to do your laundry and run your baths for you too? At this point, you just have to buckle up, or down, or whatever way floats your boat (who am I to judge?), and do the practice that must be done if you’re serious about finding your passion. This is the part of your story where you start getting really good at doing your thing. And then you’re gonna need a purpose “At its core, the idea of purpose is the idea that what we do matters to people other than ourselves.” — Angela Duckworth Okay, so listen, you picked a thing, you liked it, you got much better at it, and now you’re sitting there feeling pretty good about yourself, aren’t you? That’s great and all, but you’re not making any money yet. And that’s a problem if you wanna pay your bills. I mean, you might not wanna pay your bills, but your bills are gonna wanna get paid! So, what can we do about that? As an example, let’s say your thing is art. Who cares? Nobody gives a heckin’ hoot. Even if you’re good at making it, it doesn’t always generate enough money to live on. People will see your fan art, or worse, your original works, and they’ll be like “cool, but what can you do for me?” And then you realize, you have to be providing a service people actually need in order for them to wanna pay you. Your passion needs to serve others. Light-bulb moment, ah-ha! So you shift gears and use the God-given talent that was floated down to you by tiny naked cherubs on a pillow of clouds that you definitely didn’t work very hard for at all to make editorial illustrations, because people need those, and now you’re getting paid. Also, a purpose might help keep you motivated or contribute to the overall enjoyment of your work and life in some meaningful way or some junk. But that’s probably all secondary to making a few greenbacks. Now that’s what I call finding your passion! To recap, it’s almost impossible to not find your passion, all you have to do is: Pick an interest and dive into it to find out if you really like itPersevere and improve your skills through deliberate practiceFind a purpose AKA a reason for people to pay you for itProfitWhich step of the journey are you on?

I’m providing you exact steps you need to take to figure out what you should do with your life. I will also include a set of questions (via our test or quiz) you can ask yourself that will help you gain more clarity. Step 1 – Keep It Simple & Have Fun First and foremost, don’t let this overwhelm you. All too often people feel stressed out about figuring out what they should do with their life that it becomes this heavy burden that it actually detours you from finding your passion in life. Take a deep breath. Relax. Have fun. And let it come through you naturally. Step 2 – Follow Your Excitement With all of the self improvement and new age rhetoric you hear out there about “following your passion”, what most people don’t talk about are the actual mechanics of how this all works. Rather than thinking of some big project or career (which in actuality is jumping too far ahead), you need to focus on small steps that you can immediately take that will set up a scenario for one of the X-Factors that I teach: synchronicity. It’s through synchronicity that will allow the pieces of the puzzle to all start to come together. When you look at the story of any successful person, you will see that it was some small tinkering, a book, a class, or something that seemed “insignificant” that led to their ultimate success. Steve Jobs took a calligraphy class that later on inspired him to start Apple. So what you need to do is ask yourself this question: What excites me right now? Then do that and when that is over follow your next excitement and then the next one and so on. Have fun and play like a little child. Have you ever seen kids play with one toy to the next? A child will be fully present in the moment playing their game until they are done with it and then will quickly move on to the next thing without even thinking about it. Kids are naturally in tune with what excites them. You need to rekindle that relationship with your inner child and play with one thing to the next and see what comes up for you along the way. I’ll show you how this worked in my life and took me from a depressed overweight teenager to a highly successful Madison Ave media executive in just a moment. Step 3 – Focus On A Theme Once you have found something that excites you, then focus on that theme: SportsMusicArtBusinessTravelPhilanthropyTeachingEtc… Whatever it is that excites you, it will be part of an overarching theme that you can connect it with that will help you learn how to discover your passion in life. The truth is that many of you are probably already doing something that is your passion but because of how society defines a “career,” you have (without knowing it) discounted it not realizing that you already found it but have minimized it thinking that “There is no way I could make money from doing this.” You would be amazed at how much your subconscious rules your life without even knowing it. As someone who spent over ten years in advertising, trust me, your mind can be controlled a lot easier than you think. Work vs Hobby As you begin this process, it’s important to pay attention if any of these things feel more like your work or if they are a hobby. There is nothing wrong with creating your work life around your hobby. I have a friend who loves to surf. That is all he wants to do. He is not interested in becoming a professional or getting sponsored or anything like that. He wants to surf every day and do it on his terms. So he moved down to Costa Rica, got a job as a waiter (at night time) so that he can surf all day. He lives a very simple life but is extremely happy. In his world, he is successful. This is why it is important that you have a clear understanding of what success means to you. Do not listen to what others define as being successful, listen your heart and do what works for you. If that means making a lot of money and working a high paying corporate job then so be it. But make sure it’s true for you. How To Find Your Passion Test Break out a piece of paper and pen (or open up a Word doc) and answer these questions: 1. What can you talk about all day without getting tired of it? 2. What do you love to learn about? 3. What products or services really excite you? 4. Who do you admire and why? 5. What do you want to accomplish before you die? 6. Who are your top three favorite companies? What do you love about them? 7. What problems are you good at solving? After answering these questions, you should notice a theme. That theme should tell you what you are passionate about.

There are two routes to accomplish this, finding your passion either within your full-time occupation or as a hobby/outside of work activity. I am going to go a different route on this answer than most other answers though and argue this: Finding your passion within work is not only nearly impossible, it is a dangerous concept. Finding your “burning passion” within a full-time occupation is, frankly, a concept many of us were “sold” as kids that is not very realistic. That is not to say it cannot be done, many people out there really like their jobs (I do, personally), but for most people works is a means to an end. And that is fine. To continually seek a job you are completely “passionate” about puts you in a precarious situation of never being satisfied with your work situation. Put bluntly, work is “work.” Even within “dream” jobs, or in roles that someone is really passionate about, there is a lot of other not-at-all passionate work that needs to get done. Sending emails, holding meetings, updating websites, traveling/commuting, writing when you don’t want to, etc. Take a moment to think of your dream job. I can guarantee there are some parts of that job that will be monotonous, will separate you physically or mentally from people you care about, or will otherwise bore you. If you happen to find a job that you like, have a boss that treats you well (or are a boss that is respected by your employees), and you work with people you enjoy being around you should be thankful. Be passionate in certain aspects of your job and for those other parts be thankful you are in a good situation.  The Other Route to Burning Passion The easier of the two options I mentioned above is to be passionate about a hobby or some other activity you are engaged in outside of work. Hopefully you can find a job that gives you time to explore this marvelous side of life - free time. Get into trail running, kayaking, bird watching, trying out new restaurants, singing, dancing, playing the guitar (alone or in a band), etc. You name it. There are literally millions of activities out there, find something you are passionate about! Not only will it be a fulfilling part of your life, in many cases that happiness and fulfillment will give you more energy to perform well at whatever you do for work.

This is hard to answer without knowing anything about the context. I'll answer from passion for pleasure . You may mean as far as a career but I'm the wrong guy for that one. I'll let you know when I have the answer in my own life lol. First and formost, try as many experiences as you can that you have never done. They don't even have to cost money. One of my passions is hiking which starts as just waking :) keep trying until one or two stand out as something you may want to try again. This brings me to my second core belief; Don't try new things looking for a passion. Try them to be in the moment and enjoy or dislike what you are doing. If you have a feeling of maybe you want to try it again, great. If not, no worries and on to the next thing. Starting with a goal of finding passion is too much pressure, you won't enjoy anything because you will feel like you aren't doing it right, leading to anxiety. ( Trust when I say, I found this the hard way) Lastly, you create passion. If you try a guitar and you get that release of dopamine, that's your brain telling you “heck yeah this is scratching my itch i want more” then allow yourself to be excited to do it again. Have pleasure in thinking about what the next step of this budding passion might be. To me that is as much fun as the activity. Before my daughter was born, I would try and find a tough interesting trail for my dog and I to hike/camp solo. I had just as much fun researching the trails and planning what gear is needed (I carry everything for 5 days on my back and the dogo used to carry 20 lbs of her own stuff), as I did the hike itself. In the end, even if you never find your idea of passion, you will have a wealth of experiences that you enjoyed on the way. Hope that helped and if not, that's cool to. It was beneficial to remind myself of the above. Peace Mike

It's pretty easy.  What do you do as soon as you get done with school/work (assuming you've not yet constructed your education/employment around your passion)?  What you talk about to your friends, perhaps incessantly?  What do you know more about that just about anyone you know?  After food and shelter, on what do you spend most of your money? That's your passion. I think you might have intended to ask "How do I go about feeling passionate about something?".  As best I can tell, you start on a new topic and have a few small initial successes, and that's enough to propel you forward to spend a bit more time with it.  If it comes easily or you're particularly intrigued then you reach a tipping point where you go into a "hyperfocus" mode where you spend a significant part of your waking hours thinking about the topic.  The initial level of talent you bring to the table is (nearly) irrelevant; most people don't spend 1000 hours getting good at something, much less 10000 hours.   The trick, if there is one, is the ability to focus.  I haven't owned a television in 15 years and I'm not on facebook.  My partner has her own passions and cheerfully supports mine.  And there's a lot of social status timesinks that I just don't bother with.  So if I need three or four hours in an evening to just sit and think about a problem, I have my life arranged so I can do that. Here's what you should take away from this:  thinking about "passion" as something you need to unearth is just as silly as thinking there is exactly one "right person" for you to spend your life with.  If you stop searching and instead cultivate your capacity to be passionate then the world will be filled with interesting problems just waiting for you to solve them.  You might latch on to one of those problems exclusively or you might spend a few years on one and pick up another.  You'll never be bored, and you'll rarely have a day when you don't know what you should be working on.

I’m answering this because the subject is near and dear to my heart as an intern for a cutting edge career exploration startup called PathSource. While your passion may seem elusive, one of the most valuable things you can do in your passion search is to stay curious. Our iOS app helps young adults pick the career that best fits their interests and ideal salary through assessments. If you’ve found something you are passionate about, stick with it! Now is the time to delve deeper, learn more, and develop you skills. However it is very rare that people find their passion on the first try. The process of finding your passion is by no means a simple or linear and many struggle with this question often. While it might be easier said than done, embrace ambiguity! If you haven’t found your passion just yet, continue exploring. The best thing you could do is to expose yourself to as many experiences and resources as possible. You can do this through starting your own projects, taking on volunteer or internship opportunities, talking with professionals in a particular field, or using a career exploration app like PathSource. The point is, that no one can take on the quest alone. It might take a few tries and it might take way more than you ever anticipated. What’s great about this time of exploration is that you get to experience what your passion really entails. Don’t be afraid to seek out these resources and ask questions, the easiest way to truly understand what you’re getting into is to hear directly from people doing what you are aspiring to do. For some, it’s about finding a balance between their passion and practicality. There are ways to still pursue a career integrating your passion while incorporating additional skills as Kyle Poehling found. Kyle works at a company named Notion Music where he works as a Marketing & Communications Manager. The responsibilities of his job ranges from web design to ad design. As he discovered, “Day jobs involving music are about as rare as they come. So when I saw the window open up, it was a no brainer.” His job is still very much music focused, but allows him to employ other skills in order to create a career he is passionate about: “As a musician, you work really hard to try to figure out how to make your craft be your career. And this is certainly a marriage of that.” For some individuals, it means not being afraid to make a change. In his interview, Zach, an Analyst for Google+ describes the journey he took to find the career he was passionate about: “I always knew I wanted to have more of a business focus but I did not know what I wanted to do in college.” What he initially thought he was passionate about did not turn out to be a good fit, “I did a real estate internship and wasn’t too crazy about it, I took a job in finance in New York after graduating and absolutely hated it and I hated the people I worked with, hated the type of work.” After those negative experiences, he felt that he needed to make a change and come out to California and explore the tech scene. While he didn’t know exactly why, he felt that “culturally that’s where [he] felt like [he] belonged.” At the end of the day Zach believes, it’s about being honest with yourself, “Some advice I’d give people if they want a job like mine, you just have to be persistent and you have to know what you want and why you want it.” While the road might be daunting or unclear, Zach assures that instinct never fails, “Don’t think too much about the long term, the perfect job for now. Just follow what you’re interested in and tell people why that’s what you want to do now and everything will fall into place after that.” Still, there are some who have known their passion from the beginning. In this interview, Maisha describes how working as an attorney is something she’s always wanted to do after she fell in love with the idea in middle school. She went to college and later to law school and passed the bar exam to become a licensed attorney. After achieving her goal, she was ready to start working. She said for her, “It was really about trying to figure out what I wanted to do. I’ve always been a community organizer/activist and always loved working with people, so nonprofit was good for me.” Staying true to herself and her passion is what drives her and others in her profession: “What I know now is that there are a lot of passionate attorneys that work in nonprofit work. Attorneys that just want to give back to the community and do the work because they have passion in their heart not because of the money they get paid.” It is easy to be passionate about something when it is going well. By no means does “passion” equate with effortlessness. While your passion might play into your strengths, finding your passion is only half the battle. The real work is maintaining it. Maintaining your hunger for your passion and translating it to a career is no easy feat. At times, you may find disillusionment in the realities of your passion. Whether you find it to be too time consuming or difficult or boring from time to time, the real test is to not abandon your passion when the going gets tough. A professor gave me great advice that I will never forget: “You can teach skills, but you can’t teach attitude.” At the end of the day, you have to find something that is both fulfilling and challenging, something that you are willing to work through when obstacles present themselves.

Dear, Your passion?Your interests?Sure? Let's first understand what I call as my passion or my interest, is it really mine? The world is full of people who pursued what they call as their ‘interest’, or their ‘hobby’, or even their ‘love’, and kept feeling as frustrated as you probably do. See, the influences that others have upon us, we resist them. So, as you are saying, your parents have a certain influence upon you. You want to resist it; you don’t feel comfortable with it. There is a constant feeling that- I am doing something under somebody’s influence or pressure. So, you turn to the mind and then we ask the mind, “What do you want?” and the mind comes up with an answer which I call as ‘my interest’. You say, “I want to pursue my interest.” So, somebody is born in a particular family, living in a particular house, in a particular street. When he is a kid there are many influences upon him. There is the influence of the father who wants him to become a shopkeeper; who wants him to take over the traditional family shop, the business. And then there is the influence of all the elder brothers, the neighbors, and the kids who are living in the vicinity, and they are playing cricket all the time. So, they take this fellow out to play cricket. Now, cricket is something that he acquires from these people, but he starts calling it ‘my interest’. And the shop is something he gets from his father and he calls it ‘father’s shop’. Look at this. Where does he get the shop from? The father. And he says, “No, no, no. I do not want to go to the father’s shop.”  It is the father’s shop. And what does he call his interest in cricket?My passion. You know, these are three levels of influence: – 1. When the influence is superficial, you call it ‘influence’. 2. When the influence is deep, then you call it ‘interest’. 3. And when the influence has penetrated the very depth of your mind, then you start calling it ‘my individuality’. So, the most sick people are those who say that this work is an expression of my individuality. Oh my God! The patient is almost beyond redemption now. What will happen? What will happen is just that you will pursue what you call as your interest only to be dismayed, only to be even more frustrated. A mad man comes and asks, “I have to go to New York. Should I travel vertically up or vertically down?” What would you suggest him? If he is giving you two choices; two options are there and he is asking, “What should I choose? Should I fly up or should I dig a tunnel all the way to New York?” What would you recommend him? Recommend him some freshly cut lemon.:) AM To get more clarity on this: http://prashantadvait.com/2015/04/17/what-are-hobbies-and-interests/ http://prashantadvait.com/?s=influence

When I was in third grade, a man came into the room to demonstrate all the instruments. He was doing this to give us an idea of what they sounded like, in hopes that some kids might want to start learning to play an instrument. When he played the trumpet, I felt like some clarion laser had pierced my heart. I knew, instantly, that this was my instrument. I played and took lessons for the next ten years, but at the end of my first year in college, I made a mistake, and I didn’t preregister for lessons for the next year. When I went to sign up for lessons, they told me I needed to audition again, and I hadn’t prepared an audition piece. I stopped taking lessons, and I stopped playing in any ensembles, and I stopped playing, period. That was the first time I learned how to punish myself by not pursuing my passion. I wasn’t going to make a living playing the trumpet. It was just for fun. So I let it go, and I spent the next forty years, falling further and further into pain and eventually depression, in part because I was doing what I thought others expected me to do, instead of doing what I really wanted to do. There is one thing that gets in the way of finding one’s passion. Unfortunately, that one thing can be very important for our survival. Human beings do so well because we have learned how to cooperate with each other. We can work together, and when we work together, we can do more than any other species on the planet. Human’s ability to cooperate has enabled us to collaborate on turning solutions to problems from ideas into reality. We now cooperate on vast levels, with billions of people working together to create safety and wealth for ourselves. Evolution has played a role in helping us cooperate. It’s probably pretty simple. Any trait that confers a survival advantage will help people who have that trait to survive and bring up their children more successfully. One of these traits is the need to be concerned with others and to fit in with others. This is important because it helps us build the trust necessary to be able to cooperate. So we have evolved to be very concerned about what others think of us. We want to do what other who are important in our lives want us to do, because that way we build up the kind of trust necessary for us to work together. This has become an incredibly strong need in most humans. We care so much what others think of us because our survival depends on it. Finding your passion is an internal process. It requires that we ignore what others want or think of us. We have to pay attention to what we love, which can be almost impossible when our parents and teachers and friends are all telling us what to do, and we want to please them because it is very important to stay in their good graces. For many, finding their passion means doing things that go against the orders or suggestions of their parents and teachers. Parents often want children to do practical things that will earn them a good living, like computer engineering or becoming a lawyer or a doctor. When a child expresses an interest in art or music or dance, parents turn them away, saying that these things can not support a family. They are childish things. Parents will tell their kids that they shouldn’t try to go to college. They can’t afford college. Or that they can’t spend their time doing anything fun, playful, or useless. Children must focus on what their parents tell them, and because we have evolved to care very much about what our parents tell us, because our survival depends on it, many of us are turned away from our passions before they even have a chance. Is it any wonder that so many people don’t know what their passion is? They were never allowed to follow one, and they quickly learned that having a passion was just not something people did. If you wanted to stay connected with family and community, you didn’t rock the boat. You did what you were told. You didn’t do what you wanted to do. After many years of doing this, so many people haven’t a clue what their passion is. They’ve been told all their lives to do as they’re told. How could they possibly know what they want if no one tells them what to do? In fact, doing what they want to do has become very unsafe. If you do something you haven’t been told to do, you might do it wrong. You might make a mistake. You might hurt someone. You might risk being ostracized from the community. To be ostracized from the community, for most of human history, has meant death. Many people have no idea what their passion is because to find it, they have to risk death. I rediscovered the importance of doing what I am passionate about because eventually, I got so sick of doing what I thought was expected of me, that I was in so much pain, I thought it would never end, unless I was dead. The one thing that gave me any relief at all, was playing my horn with others. That was the only thing I could rely on. Later on, I worked music into my recovery and eventually, it became a key means for recovery. I shouldn’t have been surprised. I was in despair because I was doing what I thought was expected. I came out of despair only when I started doing what I loved to do. If you want to see what I’m up to these days, check out Sonic Sandbox. How do people who have been pushing their passion away for most of their lives find their passion? That takes a lot of work, and oddly enough, teaching people the skills to do that has also become a part of my passion. There is a lot of pain associated with straying from your passion, and it leads many into depression, including me. Music helped me come out of depression, and I realized that what I was doing was a method that anyone could use, along with other therapeutic interventions, to cope with depression and other mental differences. I call it changing thought habits and I’ve written a lot about it here on Quora. I believe this process, good for helping people cope with mental health issues, is also good for helping people find their passion. It provides a way for people to let go of their pervasive thoughts about pleasing others, so they can pay attention to the part of their mind that knows (and always knew) what their passion was, before it was so rudely interrupted by social pressure. If you can free yourself from the pressures of meeting the expectations of others, you can create a mental or spiritual opening inside yourself that will allow you to unlock your passion from the jail you have put it in, many long years ago. This process takes a lot of work; years of work, in fact. It’s not easy. Most people only take this path if they absolutely have to — if death is pretty much the only other option. Some people are able to find their passion early. Some people create enough freedom or take enough freedom to pursue their passion. Some people never had a choice but to pursue their passion. However, most just drift away from their passion, and when they realize it is missing, it has been gone for so long and has drifted so far away, they despair of ever finding it. Fortunately, the drifting away is a spiritual thing, and if people can gain access to their spiritual side, they will find their passion was there all along. Working to change habits of thought is one way they can find their way back to their passion.

Thanks for A2A.It takes time, because we tend to think in terms of school and courses instead of thinking in terms of career and interests. Try first to imagine where you stand. Some of my students, never the majority, wanted to be leaders, and some preferred to work with companions, and some wanted to be left alone. Variable proportions of students every year dream to travel and work abroad or are set to stick around the place where they come from. Some wanted a repetitive job: a friend of mine, highly intelligent, once told me that he had never been as happy as when he had to sort cables by color and thickness. Why? My guess is that he likes above all order. Your passion is not just what you like to work on, it will be also the circumstances, what makes you happy and comfortable, so try to find out about yourself. You probably know what you do not like. If you do not like to read, there is a good chance your passion will not be to write books. But we generally like a lot of things. I suppose you took mechanical engineering because you liked a few things in it. But you also may like going to the movies or cooking or going to the opera. Your passion may be somewhere in the things you like, you just have to distinguish what is a professional and what is a personal passion. I was an oceanographer, but the activity I liked best was the measurements I had to do at a nuclear reactor. Ever since I understood why the sun is hot, I had a passion for the nuclear. Also, some passions sneak on you with time. It never came to my mind that I could be an architect. But over the years and decades, I developed a passion for it. It probably came from my irritation about the places where I lived. Poorly designed, I think. Take your time: it is like a good meal: taste everything. Tell me what feels good!

Try to find a purpose this way: Each of us sometime heard any definition of motivation. I would say that mainstream media or schools don't provide us by the real concept of motivation that is hidden quite deep. Every time you hear a word "motivation", you probably picture a situation when somebody tells you: "SON! YOU HAVE TO STEP UP AND YOU HAVE TO START WORKING ON YOURSELF IMMEDIATELY!" and you feel very motivated. You feel that NOW it is the right time to take action. That now it is the right time to start doing something. That now it is the right time to work on becoming a new person.No. That's bullshit. This motivation feels good but it is just an Outer motivation. Most of the people misunderstand what is the real motivation. As I mentioned,outer motivation feels good but it lasts only short period of time and this outer motivation is the one which they describe us. It is like a smell. You open a window and after a while you don't know that something smelt in the room. Everyone wants to be motivated. But they don't realize that they are motivated by others only from OUTSIDE. If you are motivated by something or by somebody that means you are motivated from outside. And if you are motivated from outside, it doesn't last for long time. It feels pretty good but it motivates you, it inspires you to do something only for a short time. Sometimes it lasts only seconds. Let's move on the key of the whole motivation. The key of the whole motivation is Inner motivation. Inner motivation is motivation that lasts LONG TIME. This is the motivation that we need. This is the real motivation that keeps us doing something again and again and it keeps us stuck to these actions. People want to be motivated by others(from outside) because it is easy and as I mentioned it feels good. But what about motivating ourselves to do something again and again? We find it much harder. When someone tells us some "motivational words" we feel that our bodies are full of energy. But when we have to motivate ourselves, most of the time we feel tired and bored and here comes the exceptions. Only strong individuals can motivate themselves in the way that they: 1)realize that they have bad thinking - with realizing bad thinking comes realizing of bad habits, 2)by change of thinking comes taking actions, 3)by taking actions comes habits(repeating something makes the action becoming a habit), and at the end comes 4)a new person. One of the biggest realization is that human beings are creatures of habits and creating of habits comes with taking the same kinds of actions again and again. Do you feel good when teachers or parents push you into learning? NO! So why don't you make it happen in another way? After realizing these 4 steps that I mentioned, you realize that it is not that hard. In the first step you need to realize in what way you think about everything that is around you and how you take it. By realizing this, start changing the way you think and by changing thinking you start realizing your purpose of life. Your purpose of everyday life. Your purpose of doing what you do at thepresent moment. Start by simple steps, i.e.: a) you trash talk about slim people because you are fat and you cry about being fat, then realize that it is a waste of time to cry and blame yourself and others. Start imagining how big change you can do by starting doing something. Start thinking about yourself how awesome you are and think about how much "awesomer" you can be by taking actions. b) you trash talk about your current job but you do nothing to change it. Utilize every second of your free time by thinking about how awesome it can be when you start developing yourself in some way and by becoming much more developed you can find another job much easier. Stop trash talking, it just sucks your energy. Start using this energy for something useful. For thinking about how awesome reading books is, how awesome you are because you are living on this planet and you can change yourself and become a better person.START HAVING A RESPONSIBILITY. START HAVING A CERTAIN AUTHORITY OVER WHO YOU ARE!Having a certain authority over who you are also comes with a change of thinking. From blaming yourself to starting admiring yourself. You start realizing that YOU ARE ENOUGH and YOU ARE AWESOME because you are here, AT THE PRESENT MOMENT! In the second step you can't get stuck at thinking. You have to apply your way of thinking in all the situations that you are in. You have to realize that changing of thinking isn't enough. You have to start acting by that(i.e.: You think that lying is not good, you believe in that but you also have to start being honest and stop lying.)Now you have to realize that you live in the present. You don't and can't live in the past or future. You can live only here, in the present moment. So every time think about What can I do NOW? What can I do NOW instead of watching TV? What can I do NOW instead of waiting for change?Maybe you think it is going to be hard but that's only half-true. If you have already changed your thinking, it won't be that hard to take actions as you might think. Because you have already changed your thinking. Now your new thoughts won't be like they were before: "I will do it later; I will go to learn later; Now I have to watch this film to take a rest(by the way if you want to take rest, go to sleep)" but they will be changed: "I am here, in the present moment, and what useful can I do for myself? Okay, I can go to read. Okay, I can go to learn programming. Okay, I can go to work out." And by thinking like this and acting by this thinking it will be easier and easier for you and... Actions will become your habit. In the third step after you changed your thinking and changed your way of acting, your actions are becoming habits. Do you remember my sentence "Human beings are creatures of habits."? That's exactly that.Realize what HABIT really is. Habit is something that you are used to do and you don't complain about that because ONLY YOU can choose what your habits will be - by taking the same actions again and again because of some purpose.Once your actions become your habits, you just have to keep watering a plant and it will keep growing. Keep pushing your limits, keep continuing in what you do and nothing will stop you. At the end you realize that you have become a new person. You realize that you did it on your own and you didn't need anybody to help you becauseONLY YOU CAN CHANGE YOURSELF. NOBODY ELSE CAN DO THAT FOR YOU.You had to step up, take your lazy ass off of the couch and start doing something. You had to start taking yourself as an AUTHORITY, not just the next one human living on this planet.

I was sitting in the lobby of the Brookstreet Hotel sipping my green tea when I saw a group of men walk along this man that seemed to capture all their attention. I looked closer and couldn’t believe it, I got off my chair and went and introduced myself. I told him that the night before I had written a review of his book. He’s from the UK and was living in California and here I was randomly running into someone who’s video had moved me. Who’s books had changed me. Sir Ken Robinson‘s video Does School Kill Creativity? Is the most popular video on TED: Ideas worth spreading with over 44 million views. His two books Out of Our Minds and The Element inspired me to find my passion. Different people have come up with ways of figuring out what you were meant to do. In the book The Element, Sir Ken Robinson suggests two questions: 1. What subject came easy to you in school?2. What do you enjoy doing? The goal is to merge the answers together into your work. Others have told me they swear by the this venn diagram that says you should merge together something: 1. You’re good at2. That makes people’s lives better3. That will make you feel appreciated Mythologist Joseph Campbell comes at it from a tribal mythology angle where he concludes that we should follow what brings us joy. Peter Thiel the author of Zero to One who founded Paypal and led a team to become billionaire entrepreneurs who went on to create Youtube, Yelp, Linkedin, Tesla, Space X asked his team: 1. If you had a billion dollars to spend what problem would you solve in the world? I’ve found it a hard for people to answer that one because it’s so broad so I categorized them. What problem would you solve? 1. Animals2. Health3. Planet4. Equality5. Education6. Art There may not be any set way of finding out what you are meant to be doingbut hopefully I’ve given you enough questions to ponder to find the answer.

There was a period of time in my life where scarcity was my status quo. Business was a cyclical roller coaster. Some days, my bank account sparkled with the crown of a Cash Queen. Other days, it looked like the Sahara. This feast-or-famine pattern became ingrained into my self worth, and I constantly felt like a failure. And even, sometimes, like a victim. “You’re a struggling entrepreneur,” I would tell myself, “You signed up to be poor for an indefinite period of time. Don’t complain. Just work harder.” Then one day, the stress, the shame and the heartache came to a head and I found myself on my knees in my office. I will never, ever forget this day. I had actually been here, on my knees, praying, crying and begging for a miracle, hundreds of times before. But this day was different. On this day, the pain reached a swell. I had no room left to wallow. No energy left to berate myself or my life. Instead, I began listing off, out loud, everything and everyone in my life I was grateful for, and I mean EVERYTHING and EVERYONE. I must have sat there for an hour, talking to the Universe, just sending out massive, massive love to one thing after the next. It was cathartic, emotional, and I can admit, a little dramatic. Calling BS on my feelings of unworthiness and lack to instead shine light on all that was beautiful, true and abundant in my life felt amazing. Even if it was only for an hour or so. Then…a miracle a came. Literally the next day, I got a call out of the blue from a colleague offering me a six-month consulting contract. The amount of the monthly stipend offered was so large, it put me in an entirely new tax bracket. Soon thereafter, more financial opportunities like this starting rolling in. This contract led to three more contracts, freelance gigs starting picking up, I was getting approached by young women asking me to coach them, and on and on. This all happened in the span of less than one month’s time. I didn’t question the irony of this timing. I simply and humbly accepted that the Universe had just given me one hell of a message. I hadn’t been waiting for the Universe. It had been waiting for me. When we stop focusing on what we don’t have and focus on what we do, we open the floodgates to true abundance. Something else shifted that month besides the numbers in my bank account. My attitude about money completely changed, and I truly believe it was this change in perspective that continued to propel my financial opportunities: Poverty isn’t synonymous with nobility. It just plain sucks. It’s perfectly okay to say “I desire to be wealthy!” and then to go forth and create it. Abundance is awesome and something we should all strive for and celebrate. (Especially when it’s sourced from following our bliss.) I have learned that we are all destined and designed to be prosperous, and there really is enough to go around. Abundance provides us more time, which leads to more freedom, which leads to more joy, which opens up our lives for more opportunities to serve. Period. Look, I know it’s a LOT easier to talk about money this way once you have some. But during what was one of the most painful and poor times in my life, I came to realize it’s not money that fires me up at all. It was during this time that I discovered what fires me up WAY more than making money. In truth, it is this fire that inspired me to create the brand SimplyBe. It was during this time that I did. It’s the real reason I am writing this blog and why you are reading it. Here’s what fires me up more than anything: People who truly love themselves, own themselves and cherish themselves. People who boldly shine their light and never apologize for it. People who are confident enough to let the shine of OTHERS illuminate them, not threaten them. People who hustle. People who take big-ass risks and aren’t afraid to fly. People who take big-ass risks and aren’t afraid to fall. People who know that falling is not only par-for-the-course, but a gift that makes us better. People who understand that true abundance comes from the things that have absolutely nothing to do with money: love, joy, connectedness and spirit. People who create, innovate and lead as individuals, and are empowered by a community of women doing the same. What fires YOU up more than anything? Did it take hitting a breaking point to discover it? I want to know your story. That story is part of YOUR brand.

I think you have to start by distinguishing between what you want and what you care about.     That seems like an odd thing to say, perhaps.  In our culture, it is generally assumed that these are one and the same, yes?   I care about what I want and I want what I care about.   At least, that's the default thinking, I believe. But I don't think that it's quite true.   There's  a difference between my wants and my assessment of what's important.   The things that are really important are what I care about.  What I want comes and goes, more like the weather.   What I care about is more stable: it has longer time horizons than wanting. Here's  an experiment:  next time you find yourself with a break from work or whatever, plop down in a chair and look out the window.   Notice the thoughts that come into your head.    I bet if you're like most people, one of the first thoughts is some form of "ok, what do I want now?".     One of the first things an idle mind does is try to come up with a new thing to want!  I find this rather amusing, it's a game I  play myself.    I'm free, relaxed, comfortable -- and, well, that's not enough, right?  I should want something too... maybe a snack, or a beer, or some entertainment.  New shoes, I dunno, something.    But none of that stuff is important, really.  The stuff that's important is going to demand more from me than "go to the fridge, get the beer".   It's going to ask me to be someone that I'm currently not -- someone more capable, more committed, more creative perhaps.     And  I think that's key: the stuff you're going to be passionate about is the stuff that's going to change who you are -- that's the stuff that's important.  It's fine to get a beer or new shoes and to have wants, but if you distinguish those from what is going to make a difference, you're more likely to find some passion waiting to be awakened.

Passion comes from investing yourself fully into something you love. Contrary to popular belief, you never find passion. It’s not something you stumble upon or that just appears in front of you out of thin air. Passion is not a random gift you find lying on the street. It is a willow tree in your mind that was grown from a simple sapling.  People misunderstand passion as being a singular thing. There is only one passion in life, only one thing that you will love forever and only one true calling. There is only one gift-wrapped present waiting for you to be opened, and if you do not feel truly passionate then you haven’t found that gift yet. This just isn’t true. What’s closer to the truth is if you think about your desires like an open field filled with tiny, little saplings. Every one of these saplings is a desire, like or joy you have for something. And just like a normal sapling, if you do not give your joys time, energy and love they will eventually wither with time. You’ve had many joys already that you have not spent anything on and that you have then lost to time. Maybe you got lucky enough and stuck something through. If you did you will notice that, where once was a sapling, is now a beautiful willow standing in it’s place. That Willow is what Passion is. Passion is nothing more than a desire, like or joy that you invested in. It’s something you developed, grew and put in so much energy that you grew more interested and passionate about it day by day. As you got better at what you enjoyed you wanted to invest more time into it. As you developed a deeper understanding for it you wanted to learn even more. And as you spent more time into it you got more out of it. All of this, put together into one place, can be considered Passion. And it’s the same way no matter where you go. If you do not invest time and energy into a relationship it will eventually die of neglect. If you do, however, invest, then the relationship will thrive. Relationships, Work, Hobbies, Friendships, Money, Success, etc. Anything you can be passionate about follows this same process. Whether or not a like turns into a passion depends on your investment.  What that means to you, who has not “found” their passion yet, is that you simply need to pick something to invest into. Whatever you want to become passionate about, invest your time, energy, and soul into the already existing like and it will, eventually, grow into a full-blown passion. Start with something you enjoy, but pick something you want to further develop. And then learn as much as you can about it, challenge yourself to get as good as you can in it, and invest as much energy and time as you can muster.

Here is a logical approach to discover passion. 1.PERSPECTIVE MATTERS Even a mile starts with a footstep.However in this, the initiation is the thought. we need to enter by showcasing all the positive attributes of the passion. A weed can destroy entire crop.Its our attitude that lays as the foundation for the building. 2.KNOCK ALL DOORS!!! But one may find it a bit troublesome because every flavor is an interesting ones, and hard to make a choice. 4.Recollect the past and your interests with the jobs.
