I suggest to my philosophy students a simple exercise that might help. Ask yourself these 4 questions: What do you want to learn?What do you want to experience?What do you want to contribute?What do you want to leave behind?Based on these, you might find some things that will spark and lead to a passion. You might also find Ken Robinson’s book The Element: How Finding Your Passion Changes Everything to be a good read. In thinking about what your passion might be, you may also want to consider some alternative views on the entire idea of passion. Here’s a good place to start: Think Tank: Ever felt like your job isn't what you were born to do? You're not alone Dan Pink’s advice in the column is to stop thinking so much about what you might be passionate about and stop worrying about whether you will ever find your passion. Instead: do something. Act! As he puts it: Ask yourself some questions like these: What did you do last Saturday afternoon – for fun, for yourself? What books do you read or blogs do you visit, not for work, but just because you're interested in them? What are you great at? What comes easily to you? What would you do – or are you already doing – for free? As it happens, I can testify to the power of de-emphasising passion and re-emphasising doing. Beginning about two decades ago, I worked in some very demanding, intensely stressful jobs in American politics and government. But throughout – on the side, usually for no money – I wrote magazine articles about business and work, and formulated ideas for books. At one level, it was foolish. I lost sleep, sacrificed leisure, and probably distracted myself from my paid employment. But after many years, it finally hit me: This – not politics – is what I did. And now, as a result, that's what I do. Am I passionate about it? Sure, I guess. Maybe. Some days. But passion isn't something I much ponder. I'm too busy doing what I do. You might find Dan’s Book on motivation interesting as well. It’s titled Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates us.

Firstly I would recommend you ask yourself some basic questions.Such as- “What do I like?”“What interests me?”“What makes me curious?”And“What do I feel an urge/impulse to do in life?” There will, probably, not be any single answer to any of these questions. But, should you have any trouble finding answers to any of them then I suggest using the worlds greatest resource, the internet, to your advantage. Search through hobby, creative, artistic, craft, sport or any other websites that peak your interest.Remember, everyone is different. So it is about finding what you want to do. Create a list of things you would like to try, learn or do.Organise this list in order of easiest to achieve down to hardest to accomplish.Then work through the list.I advise keeping a written record of your experiences with each one, and how they made you feel. This isn’t necessary for finding things you are passionate about. As you will know them when you try them. But it is an interesting thing to look back on. And it can help you discover what additional skills you have that can be transferred to other areas of your life, or put on a resume. I am sure, in time, you will find several things that you are passionate about. And that you love to do. With luck you may be able to find how to make a living doing them. And that is a good route to finding true happiness and contentment in life! I wish you all the best on your journey of self discovery!And I hope you find lot’s of enjoyment along the way!

People aren’t going to like my answer. Hear me out though. Your passion isn’t going to be found by asking this question. And it’s not going to be found my reading any of these answers. If you’re looking to find your passion, you need to try new things. You need to push your boundaries. You need to see the world. And you need to meet new people. If you feel like you’re in a bubble, get out. I grew up in Maryland. The east coast was a great place to grow up, but I wasn’t into the politics that came with living right outside DC. I moved to San Diego for college. It was a life changer. Living by the beach, in one of the nicest cities in the world, has taught me so much about people and the environment. After four years here in college, I felt like I wanted a new adventure. So, I bought a one way ticket to Europe. I spent four months traveling. Seeing the world. Meeting new people. Trying new things. That experience taught me about getting out of my comfort zone. I can start a conversation with anyone anywhere. I can feel comfortable living out of a suitcase. I can adapt to different cultures while learning about the amazing people in our world. After three months traveling, I got tired. I wanted to stay put. I had an idea for a startup and was going to start it. I moved back to San Diego. Found a new home downtown. Starting working in the best incubator here. And started my company, Sourcify. If I hadn’t traveled, would I have had the motivation to start? Would I have established a global network? Would I be willing to devote the next ten years of my life to building this company? To find your passion, you need to try new things.  ^One of my favorite days traveling Europe. Friends and I rented our own boat and drove it around the island of Capri! I called myself “captain” lol

One approach would be to try doing nothing and see if that gives you any ideas. Quit your job, quit washing your clothes, sell your furniture, sell your TV (don't sell your computer!), live on onions and cabbage and brown rice. See how you like it. You can spend all day at your passion if your passion is cheap--if your passion is writing or reading or composing computer music or computer graphics or volunteer journalism or computer animation or internet porn or listening to music or watching DVDs or computer programming. Even video work is cheap with modern SD-card video cameras. I got a good consumer HD camera on Ebay for $50. Technology makes indulging your passions real cheap. Even living in your car you can work on a laptop. If you don't like sitting around and engaging in low-cost passions, maybe you have expensive passions that will require that you find a way to make money. With that in mind, get your skills and interests evaluated by a professional counselor. It could be that (for example) becoming the Dr. House of malfunctioning Priuses you could make lots of money and still have energy left over at the end of the day (and maybe even in time open your own shop so you can make LOTS of money!) If you don't like sitting around with your low-cost passions, and more money for your passions is not going to help, then even working in a convenience store or driving a taxi or checking baggage at the airport starts to sound like an attractive proposition. There's nothing wrong with that. Another approach would be to look around for someone you admire, and try to be like that person. If you can not find anyone you admire, then you should consider the possibility that you are clinically depressed and that psychotherapy and/or medications might improve your life. Sometimes your passions will find you. Sometimes a man does not become a man until his life demands it of him.

3 steps to find what you love doing You can earn with a lot of uncommon things money. One of my favorites I had ever heard was about learning cats how to use the toilet! “Choose a Job You Love, and You Will Never Have To Work a Day in Your Life” said Arthur Szathmary*. But how would you find that one job you are really passionate about? So far nobody got paid for hanging out on the couch, binge-watching Netflix and eating Pizza, right?  Here is a simple 3-step process to come up with idea of your passions that might lead to a job or even better, a business of your own! Step 1 – Brainstorming ideas This will take you maybe 15 minutes – excluding the time you need to find friends and colleagues which you should also ask! Take an empty, white sheet of paper and write down whatever comes to your mind. Do not think whether it is a “good” or “bad idea”. Just write it down! Answer each of the following questions: 1. What skills and expertise do you have and you are good at? This can come from your formal education or your job, e.g. copywriting, software developing, creating presentations, bookkeeping, graphical design, communication, etc. 2. What are other people saying you are good at? Very often we are not even aware of our strengths, ask your friends and colleagues! They might have surprises for you. Take them seriously and write them down! Hint: You can also ask your mum. We can cross that out later! 3. What problems in your life did you successfully overcome? We grow with challenges. Have you been a shy person who couldn’t talk to anyone and found a way to overcome? Have you been in financial trouble and figured out a way to solve that? All of those might be great ideas because it tells people you “already succeeded” in something and provide your knowledge to others. 4. What would you do if you had all the money and time in the world? Just because you don’t get paid for what you love does not mean it couldn’t be a great business idea. Are you into fashion? Do you spent a lot of time designing your garden? Are you tuning your car on the weekends? You should have now a list with at least 25 ideas!  Step 2 – Eliminate what you hate doing The next step is to eliminate any idea where you might have a great skill or expertise – but you actually hate doing it. Scratch it, gone! Here is a big trap though: Passion alone will get you nowhere. It is no guarantee for success. However I believe it is absolutely necessary to love what you are doing. Unless you have absolutely no emotions and no interest in a great life. So don’t be fooled and just in for the money. A rich life is more than making money. Step 3 – Assess the potential profitability Now comes the last and extremely important step. Before you can even think of going out and starting your business you must figure out as early as possible if any of your ideas is actually going to be profitable. Basically you must be able to answer 2 questions: Profitability: Are there many people out there who would be interested in your idea?Ability and willingness: Are those people interested also able and willing to pay money for that?These questions are topics for itself, but only if you can answer both with “yes” you have a potential winner! * I found it hard to have full confidence of attributing this quote to Arthur, so let me know if you know more

The whole concept of “finding your passion” is flawed and over-sensitized. There’s never an ideal age or time or situation for passion. Finding passion is more about finding the right balance between your liking and skills. Most people focus too much on just one of these two things. One needs to accept the fact that one may like something that he/she isn’t very proficient or skillful at or that one may be skillful at something that he/she doesn’t like as much. “Everyone thinks that passion = 100% choice of interest + 100% being skillful in it. But in reality, its all about finding the right balance and accepting that perfectionism is unattainable.” But how to find the right balance? There’s no better judge than your inner instinct. We all have that one inner voice which keeps telling us so many things. But we, being too naive and unmindful, keep ignoring and dismissing it as just another wishful thought. But in reality, it is this voice that can make us do a lot of constructive things in life. We all keep hearing it. But only a few listen to it. They are too scared to take any risk. Well, some risks are worth taking. I would rather live a life taking risks, than live one with regret of not having taken any risks. Having said that, it doesn’t just end at taking risks.Honest and persistent effort, without caring about the result, is what determines how successful one would be! And if you are scared of going in the wrong directs, then don’t worry. Its easy to get lost and give up. But you have to keep going and trust your instincts. There will be many people who will pull down your confidence, but the trick is – Keep believing in yourself and your capabilities.If you don’t believe in yourself, no one else will! Also, does this assure success? Not everything is empirical. But – “If it has to happen, it will happen”! Read more @ All about Passion

Every one of us has an internal compass called emotions. That’s literally what they were made for: To steer us away from the things that harm us and towards those things that are for us. When you do something and from it you get a feeling of inspiration, flow and a desire to do and be more, that are the first indicators for passion. Exercises that can help you with digging deep are all kinds of reflective and introspective practices, everything that helps you dig up your thoughts and emotions and their causes. A few things to consider while trying to find your passion: It takes time and introspective work to find it. It won’t appear on the day you ask the question. It’s a learning process, so give yourself the time you need.Passion comes from being good at something. One of my big passions nowadays is Martial Arts. But when I started Martial Arts 6 years ago, I wasn’t passionate at all about it. The only things I felt while training was that nothing worked, I wasn’t able to do the movements and it hurt. But with time, I got better at it and it started becoming more and more fun until I was euphoric while training every time. What I want to say is: The thing you are passionate about might in the first times you are trying it cloak itself in fear, failure and a need for growth. So whatever you try out because you think it might be your passion, try it out for a longer period of time.Passion comes from flow. Here is the definition of flow from Wikipedia: “A flow state, also known as being in the zone, is the mental state of operation in which a person performing an activity is fully immersed in a feeling of energized focus, full involvement, and enjoyment in the process of the activity. In essence, flow is characterized by complete absorption in what one does, and a resulting loss in one's sense of space and time.” If you want to find passion, follow the things where this positive immersion comes up for you naturally.I hope this was helpful. If you would like some personal guidance, I offer a coaching program where I guide you through the process of going both within and without to find your passion. If you would like to hear more details about that, send me a message here on Quora or on Instagram to @firewings_motivation. Looking forward to talking more to you about this! All the best,Sabine

Editoro,  Hello, nice to meet you, great name, and thank you for the A2A.  This is a serious question and I want to give you some serious research and a serious answer.  At 19, I too was in a school that I didn't think was good for me (although my father did) and had to make a similar decision at your age.  Somedays I regret my choice, other days I don't.  So, I know its a big deal for you now and will be for you 30 years from now. I merged your two Quora questions before answering. Then, I researched you and your school a bit more and thought WOW, This kid got accepted to University of Uyo in Nigeria and is what we might call here "pre-law".   That's a huge accomplishment and I'm sure your parents are proud.   They named you Editor (19 years ago) and probably hoped you'd have a way with words and perhaps they even have subscribed to the pen is mightier than the sword belief since before you were born. Then I decided to check out your choice of profile picture:  Arvin Lal.  I had never heard of Arvin, so I looked him up: This 28-Year-Old Built A $3 Million Business In 10 Months Thanks To Instagram, He Says Wow, I wanted to learn more about Arvin.  I wonder if Arvin went to school, did he graduate?  So I looked Arvin up on LinkedIn: Arvin Lal  and yes, Mr. Lal worked very hard (2o hours a day he says in his videos) to earn two degrees, and I suspect that his MBA informs his business decisions and much of the brand persona building he is doing today.  I suspect he is also informed by the many writers, editors and lawyers he hires and works with as he creates his image and product marketing campaigns.    So now to your questions: How can I go about finding my passion?If law is not my passion, then how do I tell my parents?School work is very different than career work, so I would not judge future happiness in a career by your passion for the coursework.  Because some of the law classes can be tedious.  Before making a choice to change or to drop out, I would suggest that you pause.   Pause the decision by either continuing with classes and slogging through for the moment while exploring what you really want, or talking to the school about pausing your program, doing some passion finding exercises, changing your choice of studies.  Your school has a lot of resources to help you out.  You may want to start with your librarian, and perhaps a student advisor. I noticed that Uyo has many programs, so there is a lot to explore:   You are not the first student to have this concern and your university may have an office that helps students figure things out.   The school and your parents really want you to work hard, to love it and to thrive! For finding your passion there are a few exercises I like to suggest:  Time tracking, make a log and keep track of what you do during the day.  Write down what it was, how much you liked it, why you liked it.Library exploring, take yourself to the library, or really good bookstore, walk around the whole place.  Find at least 20 books that call to you.  It can be anything:  sports, health, photography, animals, spirituality, law, environment, sex appeal, technology, graphics, art, 3D printing, Brain Wave Recognition, Internet, Travel, Farming, Fiction, comics, video games, entertainment.   Take this stack to a table, flip through them, skim read as you like, as you do it make a few piles sorting the books by how they made you feel.   The great, good, indifferent, bad, and terrible.  Whatever makes sense to you.  Then look at the piles, which one is bigger?  Which one do you love more?  Which one do you hate?  Which pile of books would you like to be stuck with for the next few years?  Write down your feelings and what you learned about yourself.  (then offer to help your friend the librarian to put all the books back).Ask people who know you.  Ask your grand parents, ask your friends parents, as your spiritual leader.  Ask your wise friends, Ask your idiot friends.  Ask them:  When have you seen me happiest?  Weigh all these view points and write that down.Sit quietly, by yourself, close your eyes, and clear your thoughts, and do this until you have only your thoughts and examine what they are.Ask people in the prospective professions being considered.  What is the real job like? Why do you love it?  Are there specialties more interesting than others?   For example specialties in law: business law, media law, sports agent law, contract law, constitutional law, court litigation.Notice the things in life that really bug you, can you make a career out of fixing those things?Notice the things in life that just make you feel great, can you make a career around that?Make a pros/cons list, or chart, or map of all your thoughts.Can you finish and get a university degree?   What would you really like for yourself?   What sort of life or career will that mean for you?  Will you be happy and passionate and proud of your decision?Then maybe you are ready to tell your parents that you know what you like, what you are passionate about, and what you plan to do with the next few years.  Give your parents some credit, they really want you to thrive, because if you do they will rarely have to worry about you.Parents, Universities and Degrees are all great things to have in your life, please appreciate all that you have!Perhaps, in a few years you will be Mr. Arvin Lal's representative in Africa.   He will expect you to be your best. (I added this Sept 1, 2015)Best wishes!  I'm curious for your next question and to see what happens!   Please message and let me know.

My definition of passion: An intense enthusiasm for a subject or activity -pretty straightforward. What makes you feel passionate about in life? Passion is the fuel that can help you turbocharge your manifesting skills. Without passion, your life will seem like a mundane mess. The secret to living with passion is to become passionate about being passionate. That’s it. Just make being a passionate person your number one priority every day, all day. Passionate people are driven at every level and every stage of their lives. It’s not that hard once you get the ball rolling. You can become passionate about anything. Grocery shopping – check, paying your bills on time – check, doing work you already enjoy – check. Passion is the secret sauce to life. Look at passionate people and observe how they always outdo their competitors. Take two people and give them a restaurant with the same tools and resources. I promise you that the more passionate of the two will be more successful. How interested are you in changing your life? Your behavior and your actions are the keys to transforming yourself. I know you heard the phrase, follow your passion right? This means whatever makes you come alive with excitement and vigor is the right path for you at that moment. Let’s say making and baking brownies is the most exciting and passionate thing you do. Now let’s say you’ve been making and baking brownies every day for a year and now you’ve lost your passion and excitement for doing this. Now what? You are no longer a passionate person because that thing you were excited about no longer makes you feel that way. What to do, what to do? Good, you just realized it wasn’t the thing that you were doing that you were passionate about. What you accomplished if you were paying attention is that what made you feel excited about was your passion for life. It was never about the thing itself; it was about what you were feeling within your body that made you excited. You are passionate and when you don’t feel passionate about your life you blame it on outside circumstances. The truth is you decide whether or not you start your day off passionate or not. You get to choose; it’s your choice. Once you learn to make passion a priority I promise you that your life will reflect that to you in positive ways. What kills your passion? Without a doubt, the number one passion killer is negative beliefs and definitions about who you are and what you can become. Beliefs at their core are just thoughts you keep having again and again and again and again. The only difference between you and Gordon Ramsay are passion and beliefs. He believes he can do anything and maybe you do not. You must exhibit a passion for creating desire. That’s the secret. Whatever you are doing, be passionate about it. That’s it – it’s not that difficult to understand. Here’s your assignment. Everything you do after reading this post, do it with passion. And then go ahead and do it tomorrow, and the next day and the next day and the next day, and then keep doing it. You must exhibit a passion for creating passion! So, let’s say you are feeling stuck in your life. You can’t manifest change to save your life. The secret here is to begin moving and acting passionately. What happens when you do this is that your outer world will change according to the state of being you are projecting outward. Remember, this is the mirror or reflection technique. What the outside world is displaying to you is just a manifestation of your inner world. Change your inner world, change your outer world, so keep moving and acting passionately. You can’t give up here; you can’t quit. Live with passion as Tony Robbins so eloquently states. Go ahead and do it now! Be hungry, be driven, be obsessed with living with a passion so you can create the necessary vibrational state so you can attract what you prefer into your life. Do it now! Find Your Passion Finding your passion is easy once you know where to look for it. Passion is found within yourself, and you’ll know you found your passion when you ‘light up’ while doing it. Finding your passion is done through emotion and not intellect. What did you love as a child? Were you creative?Did you love learning new things?Were you a people person?Did you love to teach?Did you love to read?Was your imagination powerful?To keep your passion high, you need to take a break from your passions so you can rebalance yourself. It’s not that you are giving up on your passions, it’s that with a break from them you get to rest yourself and renew your desires. >>>Become Passionate About Being Passionate

Remember back when you were a kid? You would just do things. You never thought to yourself, “What are the relative merits of learning baseball versus football?” You just ran around the playground and played baseball and football. You built sand castles and played tag and asked silly questions and looked for bugs and dug up grass and pretended you were a sewer monster. Nobody told you to do it, you just did it. You were led merely by your curiosity and excitement. And the beautiful thing was, if you hated baseball, you just stopped playing it. There was no guilt involved. There was no arguing or debate. You either liked it, or you didn’t. And if you loved looking for bugs, you just did that. There was no second-level analysis of, “Well, is looking for bugs really what I should be doing with my time as a child? Nobody else wants to look for bugs, does that mean there’s something wrong with me? How will looking for bugs affect my future prospects?” There was no bullshit. If you liked something, you just did it. The problem is not a lack of passion for something. The problem is productivity. The problem is perception. The problem is acceptance. The problem is the, “Oh, well that’s just not a realistic option,” or “Mom and Dad would kill me if I tried to do that, they say I should be a doctor” or “That’s crazy, you can’t buy a BMW with the money you make doing that.” The problem isn’t passion. It’s never passion. It’s priorities. And even then, who says you need to make money doing what you love? Since when does everyone feel entitled to love every fucking second of their job? Really, what is so wrong with working an OK normal job with some cool people you like, and then pursuing your passion in your free time on the side? Has the world turned upside-down or is this not suddenly a novel idea to people? Look, here’s another slap in the face for you: every job sucks sometimes. There’s no such thing as some passionate activity that you will never get tired of, never get stressed over, never complain about. It doesn’t exist. I am living my dream job (which happened by accident, by the way. I never in a million years planned on this happening; like a kid on a playground I just went and tried it), and I still hate about 30% of it. Some days more. Again, that’s just life. You have just believe in yourself and had crouge yo follow its…….

Last year, I found myself at 25, too, wondering how I had gotten so lost.  I found myself slipping away from what I had once thought was my passion; I wanted to pursue a career in academia, becoming a psychology researcher and professor. The problem was, that was all I knew. I had never really allowed myself to branch out beyond what I had studied in college, thinking at the time that this is what I was good at, and with all the time and effort I had put in to mastering one subject, why on earth would I try to study anything else? All that changed when I stepped into a bookstore around this time last year, and bought a book on something I knew nothing about: programming.  Because I had worked in clinical psychology in the past, I had all these ideas tucked away in my head on how I could help people with clinical disorders via mobile technology. It was all I needed to get hooked into trying something new. And once I began programming, it was as if I had discovered something unlike anything I had ever done before. It was a science, yet an art. It was intellectually stimulating, and challenging, but oh-so rewarding.  Receiving instant feedback from the computer, even after dozens attempts of errors, yielding just one successful result was the most rewarding thing I had ever felt. I had built that. Actually built that.  It's like a chef who had baked dozens of soufflés, only to see them collapse right out of the oven, but with enough persistence, manage to pull off the most perfect, extravagantly fluffy soufflé. What a rewarding feeling. Leveraging the same metaphor, having the newfound knowledge-- and courage!-- to release my first iPhone app on the App Store, was like sharing that soufflé with the world.  It took a lot of time, persistence, and a dash of risk-taking, but with the discovery of my new passion, I decided to take this new hobby and turn it into a career. I quit my job, spent months prepping for technical interviews, and decided to travel the world for the first time. The happy ending to my story is that I found a new job as an iOS developer, and even to me, it's still difficult to wrap my head around what just happened in the past year of my life. I've made an incredible transition into a new career I'm immensely passionate about, and it all started with one trip to my local bookstore. I think the key to my story is that passion follows discovery. And once you recognize it as a passion, to run with it. You first have to be open-minded and curious enough to learn something new and experience the unknown, and then driven enough to stick with it, and courageous enough to take risks for it. For me, once I let myself take the risk to quit my job, I decided to travel. And that, too, was one of the most eye-opening, rewarding experiences for me. I think if I had let myself continue doing what I wasn't so passionate about, I would have never found the courage to try something new and travel either. I wish you the best of luck in all your endeavors. Your passion is there -- it's just waiting to be discovered in a book, article, or maybe even here on Quora :)

I would sit in my room scared some days. Questioning my existence. Scared that I don’t know what I want in my life. I still don’t. I am still scared. But I force myself out of bed every morning. Keep up with my work. I feel scared again. But I go to classes. Try to read more. Try to fall in love again. Sometimes I feel like giving up. Sometimes I feel what’s the point. But I still drag myself to eat. Then I do my work and try to sleep on time I feel so scared some days I can’t even breathe. But then I work again every morning. I would listen to music. Talk to my sister. Laugh around with my friends. I would watch interviews of my life ideals, Ben Frankin, Elon musk , Charlie munger. I would try to improve myself. Then I would pray. Pray for love. Pray for meaning. Pray for health. I don’t know what passion means. I never looked up in the dictionary. I pretend I know the meaning so that people think I am smart. A mother takes care of her child. Change his diapers and cleans him. She doesn’t enjoy it. She does it because of her oxytocin connection. I don’t know what passion means. So I look for oxytocin instead. I felt a great oxytocin connection to help others. It was so strong that I would work everyday 15 hours. But I started pondering more.Then I stopped believing in the idea. I became cynical. Then I sat in my room depressed and sad and unmotivated. Then I started feeling oxytocin in my life again to join a great startup trying to help the humanity. Then I started pulling off 15 hours again in life. I was bathing in oxytocin again. I hated the work. It was painful. It was oxytocin which kept me going. Then I lost faith in it. I felt my contribution was almost laughable. I lost the connection. Then I got depressed and sad again. Now I am in the gutter trying to build my oxytocin again. Oxytocin needs a healthy body. It doesn’t come to a body if you are not healthy. I need to improve physically, emotionally , mentally and spiritually everyday first. (Shoutout to James Altucher) Then I would find my oxytocin belief again.Then I would go back to 15 hours a day routine again. People look for dopamine in their work.That’s why they lose. Oxytocin is gazillion times stronger than dopamine. It’s hormone for love. It trumps enjoyment and pleasure every time. If you look for enjoyment in your work. You will lose. Every damn time. If you get goosebumps while thinking about work even though you hate it, you have a oxytocin relationship. You have a shot at winning. Simon Sinek says look for why if you wanna develop your oxytocin relationship. Wright brothers had a why. Their competitors lost because they didn’t. Wright brothers succeeded because they kept trying even though they failed a lot of times. They were not enjoying building a plane. But they would get goose bumps pondering at the possibility for us to fly. They had a oxytocin relationship. If you don’t have one and you are lying depressed and sad in the gutter instead like me. Do what I am doing. Become healthier instead. Shubham Jain's answer to I feel alone. What should I do? Then your body will be ready for oxytocin. Without oxytocin, I feel scared, depressed, sad and lonely. But I pick myself again everyday to find it. Maybe I will look for the meaning of passion in the dictionary. Or write a letter to Oxford people to change the meaning in the dictionary. Maybe they will change it. Or maybe they will have a good laugh. I hope we can laugh together.
